description:
Dim sum on the go is becoming a life style. Days like today when there is no traffic, door to door in 25 min. And the sun is bright even in the inner richmond and Sunset, make you feel blessed to be a Bay Area resident! 
A stop for Dim Sum, then Blue Bottle in HV on the way back over the BBridge; lid open on the whip, Winston charming passers by with dumbo ears flying free out of passenger side, as we amble through. 
I spied this place thinking I needed cash at the B of A across the street. The line was long a great sign!  so I tied Winston up to a bike pole next to a Yorkie and got in the queue.

Lots of delicious choices. I got shrimp spring rolls and a shrimp chive thing that looked like a samosa or an empanada. Apparently filled with onion chives shrimp and ginger. 
The spring roll I woofed in route to Hayes Valley. Upon securing my Iced coffee at BB, Winston and I chilled while I ate the Chinese empanada. Oh snap! of course I brought dog treats and agua for Sir Winston. Otherwise I could not focus on that very satisfying treat. Those big brown eyes ever alert for a "damn you are so freaking cute sympathy snack". Sorry I don't remember the name, and no Winston did not get any. 
My new fav! 
This is the spot man!  XL Bao made fresh, lots of unique choices, takes plastic CC (cash is ok too) fast fresh and convenient! 

No fog or traffic going into the city on a weekend morning? Look for me and Winston heading to Clement!
author: Craig G.

description:
10/10 recommend!!! Dumplings are my #1 favorite and there is no better place to get them than Xiao Long Bao. I have only lived in the bay for 3 months and I have been here...4 times now? While fitting in all the other new places I've tried, consider me impressed with myself.

Located in Inner Richmond (which is absolutely the best area to get Chinese and Vietnamese food) - don't waste your time in Downtowns Chinatown if you want something authentic that is also reasonably priced. The restaurant has many of their buns and pancakes already made and in the glass cases as you walk in. Most of their dumplings are made to order so they will take a few minutes to cook. Do not be fooled by the labels on the glass cases! They do not match the food sitting behind them. Order what you want based on the menu and don't expect it to look how you think it will, just know that it will be delicious!

Things I suggest you try:
1. Pork or beef pan fried bao (comes with 3)
2. Beef or green onion pancake (comes with 1 large pancake)
3. Potstickers (comes with 6)
4. Chili pork dumplings - spicy (comes with 10)** so good
5. Xiao Long bao (comes with 6)

Honestly, anything you order will be good. I have tried a few other things on the menu that were good but they needed some extra flavor with soy sauce or hot sauce, which is why they did not make my top 5 list. Everything above is amazing on its own. If you want to take your food to go they give it to you that way already, but there are also tables in the back of the restaurant for you to sit in should you want to stay! 

The woman at the front desk is a little demanding in wanting you to order quickly so you can feel a little pressure, so I recommend knowing what you want in advance if you can. Don't let her pressure you so much that you forget to order something!! She just wants the line to go quickly as it's usually out the door.
author: Bri T.

description:
You'd think for as many times as I've bought delicious dumplings and dim sum that I would've tried their namesake Shanghai soup dumplings (XLB) but I haven't.

I don't know why, maybe I'm a contrarian. 

But I've become a huge fan of Xiao Long Bao's wonton soup, har gao, siu mai and these deep-fried little footballs of chewy dough filled with savory chopped pork. They're melt-in-your-mouth delicious. 

And, you might agree Xiao Long Bao's baked BBQ pork buns are some of the best in the city: Filled with saucy, delicious BBQ pork, they're a warm and filling meal unto themselves. 

While I wait for my order of wonton soup, I watch the hard-working women toggle between their sister restaurant Clement BBQ two doors down, bringing over spring rolls or a miniature loaf of butter cake to complete a customer's order.

Before everything is readied to go, I glance over to the storefront counter and watch dumplings being methodically rolled out, filled, folded and pinched; it's a slice of San Francisco and it tastes delicious.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
So sad the lady cashier over charged me today.. in my order I want 2 orders of potstickers. 6 pieces per order.$6+ per order and crispy potstickers 2 orders n  no chive dumplings ?? Which I also ordered 1 order which I don't see in my box..! 
So disappointed for my today visit here..$27 my order?? I have her $100-$27=?? Wonder did she give me the right change?? Beware of this place!! I won't be coming anymore!!!
author: Crisy G.

description:
This place is pretty legit. They don't have as munch variety as some other places but they offer quite a few items that are northern chinese, which is hard to find. I order some standards, such as the shumai, shrimp and chime dumplings and xiao long bao, also picked up pumpkin rice cakes, pan friend bao, coconut milk steamed buns and shrimp and chive pan fried pockets. I liked everything that I ordered and would love to go back and try out more thing. 

I also saw the kitchen steaming some baos that I could only purchase next door so will try that next time. And the place takes credit cards, unlike most dim sum take out places. Glad I found this spot!!
author: Alice W.

description:
Wow a Chinese bakery I can finally visit to get Xiao Long Baos and Pan Fried goodies to go? For sure I'm going to be coming here regularly. I don't know of any other dim sum spot in the city you can easily order XLBs or Pan Fried Baos (Shenjianbaos) fast-food style. I've been having an itching for Shanghainese style dumplings lately but would rather not deal with ordering from a restaurant. I just want quick and affordable Shanghai dumplings to go. 

So far I've tried their XLBs, fried pork buns, the pan fried chive and shrimp dumpling that looks like a potsticker, and taro and egg yolk buns. My favorite so far has to be the Pan Fried Chive & Shrimp dumpling, Pan Fried pork/beef buns, and the Taro paste bun and Egg yolk bun.  I was pleasantly surprised the distinct taste of the taro bun as it tastes like I'm biting into a fresh taro plant. The XLBs which this shop is named after was just okay though and you can probably find better ones at Shaghai restaurants. 

I have to mention my main and probably only gripe with this place is the extremely rude customer service and when I say this place, I mean one particular nasty worker who makes it her mission to give you the worst customer service possible. Every time I have come here I had the misfortune of having to deal with her. She makes you question whether you really should be patronizing this place as you have probably never felt more unwelcome in your life until you order from here. She is absolutely bitter, impatient, doesn't understand much english nor does she even try to communicate with you. This leads to misunderstandings and sometimes I suspect she may be changing the prices as she pleases as I'm not even informed of the price of one item. 

To make matters worst I think her only job function is manning the registers which makes it taxing and a grueling experience to make a order here. It feels as if applying for a coveted position to access delicious dim sum but you have to go through a hazing process of ridicule, slander, and constant sneering from this lady to be worthy of tasting delicious baos you can't get elsewhere. Hey I'll probably see this as a growing process to help me finally develop thicker skin. You should have this mentality as well cause when your dealing with 1000 joules of negative energy emanating from her you better find it humorous or else you'll be swept up by dark forces. 

In summary this place is a good dim sum addition where you can get specific types of dim sum you can't get elsewhere. Its savory good and affordable.
author: Jude N.

description:
Having a place named after an iconic dumpling dish better mean an outstanding product.  Unfortunately it was just ok. In my opinion it's no different from a regular takeout dimsum joint serving mediocre soup dumplings.  The dumplings lacked a good soup (not enough) and dumpling skin (too thick) ratio.  Surprise lay the wonton noodle soup was good and was better than the other stuff I tried (jook, beef wrapped noodles and shrimp and chive dumplings).  The service was friendly. 

There are definitely better options out there. 

Food 3
Service 4
Overall 3
author: Patrick C.

description:
Came in with our friend of Chinese heritage who knows how to order dim sum. We had pot stickers, bbq pork bao, green onion pancakes and sesame balls. The pot stickers and pancake were my favorite. The service was fast.

We took our food to go and because of that, didn't have any soy sauce which would have made our meal a little better.

All in all, I recommend this place for some dim sum.
author: Samantha H.

description:
The prices here are amazing!! 3 baos for $2.50!! You can use a credit card to pay if the total is over $10, but given how cheap everything is, you would be ordering a lot of food just to meet the minimum!! 

I loved how convenient and cheap this shop is and the food was pretty decent too. It was like paying grocery mart prices for cooked food :) I didn't try their xiao long baos but i did order a few things since I don't carry much cash around anymore: 

- pork and vegetable baos: these are pretty standard and I would say the ones here are about what'd you'd expect. Nothing fancy, but still tasty 
- sesame ball: these are good when hot! They're pretty big. I wasn't a huge fan but I'm also trying to limit my fried foods intake 
- Lou Sa Bao: dessert baos with sweet yolk stuffings. I couldn't eat anymore so I took them home and reheated them later. They were still good reheated! Lou Sa Bao are literally suppose to ooze out when you bite into them. They didn't ooze after the reheating but I still enjoyed them. 
- preserved egg with pork porridge: they will give you a huge serving for $3! 

I probably bought a whole day's worth of food for $11- unheard of in this insanely expensive city. 

Tip: to reheat your baos, you'll want to steam them. Not baked or microwaved.
author: Annie Z.

description:
Fav place to get dimsum on clement! Last year there was a fire at clement dimsum next door to this place, so Xiao Long Bao restaurant has allowed them to continue serving dimsum at their place! 

I like this place better than other to go dimsum places simply because I think the food is usually less greasy comparably. I always love to get the the shrimp dumpling, pork dumpling, chive and shrimp dumpling is also great! The pan fried pork bun is pretty good, but I also like just getting the pork meat bun ( 菜肉包子)-- the filling is basically the same for both so may not be getting both at the same time. The giant chive dumplings looks amazing (韭菜盒子)- note their version has shrimp too- on my list to try for next time!
author: Kristie M.

description: Good to go dim sum! The taro cake and BBQ pork buns were my favorite, but we ordered lots of goodies and all were cheap and tasty. I don't know what half of what I ate was and the bustle of the place made it feel hard to slow down and find out... But I know I liked it.
author: Anastasia Z.

description:
not bad, though have backup items ready to tell them since numerous things are unavailable at any given time. it's all still "dim sum", but they seemed to emphasize steamed buns & pancakes more than other dim sum places on the block.

language barrier, so i ordered by item # as my cashier bounced back & forth #ripaaliyah from the register to the food cases. patientish service and (i think) rung up the right price at the end. lots of food inexpensively.
author: Dan B.

description:
Very good priced good Cantonese food here. Very good har gow. I ordered 1 order of (3) sesame bao, 1 order of (3) egg yolk bao, 1 order of (3) taro bao, and 3 orders of Har gow. All for roughly 12 bucks. Har gow was excellent.
This locates on Clement street where gou can find other chinese stores like roasted ducks, bbq stores, supermarkets, and etc. good location for Chinese food testing in SF.
author: An B.

description:
Food: It tastes fine and is quick; if you're in front of the door and hungry, it's perfectly fine. Their signature bao/banner dish doesn't really rate much better than steamed from frozen thus the three.

Service and location: It's a Chinese quick food restaurant on clement; so you'll get the quick response move along attitude (but they're definitely not mean - just busy). 

Recommended: .....
author: David Z.

description:
Now there's a good reason this Clement Street dim sum shop is pretty empty while Good Luck Dim Sum across the street is a flurry of activity with pink order forms flying over the counter into a frenzy of clicking tongs over big bun steamers. Ah yes, that's what I was expecting here but no, it was still as a tomb with the dim sum stored away on trays in warming ovens (photo: http://bit.ly/2lmGj8A). I'm guessing the lack of turnover contributes to the lack of freshness in the dumpling department. The staff didn't look terribly busy as the kitchen was quiet with rags left around the trays covered in plastic (photo: http://bit.ly/2ltlhlz).

Despite the warning signs, I still gave it a try just picking things off a worn pink menu taped precariously to one of the ovens. Why? They were cheap and so am I, a match made in heaven. I ordered a trio of the Shrimp & Pork Siu Mai for $2.25 (photo: http://bit.ly/2ltkGjR). Lukewarm but OK for what they were. The same price applied to the three Cha Xiao Bao (BBQ Pork Bun) which were just too bready for me and rather arid in flavor, even the pork inside. The biggest disappointment was the one I never tried before, the Coconut Juice Bun, at the same price for three (photo: http://bit.ly/2ltkRM1). It was honestly a big piece of rolled dough that may have met a palm tree once. Good luck, Xiao Long Bao...I mean I'm going to Good Luck.

FOOD - 2 stars...lackluster dim sum stuck to my ribs, not to my heart
AMBIANCE - 2 stars...a little barren in there
SERVICE - 2 stars...well...
TOTAL - 2 stars...good luck...I mean Good Luck
author: Ed U.

description:
This is one of my favorite places to grab a quick order of Xiao Long Boa and either grab a quick seat or take them to go.  

The soup dumplings are juicy, savory and porky and include a small cup of some black vinegar for that perfect-seasoned taste. Other dim sum here is good, like the Har Gow but not as tasty  as the Xiao Long Bao. The steamed egg bun is a little sweet and the pork bun is hot or miss.... yet I love the quick service and freshness so I keep coming back. Also, they take credit because of the higher volume of tourists at lunch time.
author: Steve B.

description:
I cannot believe I have not written a review yet! I've been going here for years since my aunt recommended this place. There are so many dim sum places to go to on clement, but this is honestly my favorite place. Compared to other places their food is fresh and you can see it for yourself. The dim sum, noodles, green onion pancakes, etc. is not sitting there all day. Their food tastes fresh and to me tastes "clean". The prices are reasonable and I go here all the time!! I HIGHLY RECOMMEND.

Their soups are really good too and their egg yolk bao.
author: Foodie Sushi Q.

description: I like the selection they have. Had some shui mai and some soup dumplings along with other items like pancake item and something else I can't remember. I would come again for the soup dumpling! It's good. Really authentic and not expensive.
author: Kay T.

description:
It was okay. Quick grab and go Dim sum place with their speciality obviously being xlb.

Highlights are the incredibly fast service, food made fresh and virtually to order. Nothing sits out at this place for very long it looks like. Everything comes out steaming hot. 

Highlights are the chive dumplings. Perfect skin, not too thick, pan fried to perfectly. Filling was pretty good, although I wish it had more meat.

Housemade soymilk was great accompaniment, not overly sweetened. 

Sadly though the xlb was not the star of the show. Taste-wise, it's subpar. It almost tasted like it wasn't cooked all the way through even though the juices ran clear. 

Shrimp dumplings or the hargow was also okay. Dumplings skin was decent, cooked properly, but somehow its taste didn't leave me feeling wowed. 

All in all, this place is okay if you want a quick bite for wicked cheap
author: Michelle C.

description: Found this place walking down the street on Clement, got shu mai,  curry steamed buns, bbq steamed buns, and a shrimp and chives pan fried dumpling. It was all good.
author: S. G.

description:
What the heck!  This review is strictly about a bad experience which really pissed me off!  I come here often and would. Normally I would give a 3 or 4 star rating but on my recent visit I ordered the cherry pork dumplings (10 for $4.50) and potstickers (6 for $3.99) .  The gal who.normally takes my order pushed 2 buttons and says "$10". I asked me if there was tax and she says yes.  I asked where my change was and she said, "no change".   What?  The bill was $8.49 and wanted my change. She just looked away.

You have  got to be kidding!  Is this new math or dim sum math?  Made me think how many other times she has rounded up on me.  

In the end I took two sodas out of the case as I left.  I am warning anyone who comes here to ask for a receipt and make sure you do the math.  There dim sum is good and fresh but this is very poor customer relations.
author: Erik H.

description:
This is like a hole in the wall dining place. The best deal is the won ton noodle soup. It's $5.25 for a piping hot bowl made to order on the spot. There's also various dim sum and baos to order from the counter. They have fresh soy milk as well. 

It's not exactly neat and tidy inside but there is usually a line at this place.
author: W A.

description: I came here a couple of times with my parents and loved it, especially the fried shrimp rolls. I came here this morning to get a dim sum fix and an hour later, FOOD POISONING. So disappointed that I have to spend my Sunday sick. I will not be coming back anymore!
author: Aiza V.

description:
Cheap low grade xiao long bio... you can see them making it from the street.

Luke warm, no soup but reasonably tasty for $5

Shrimp and chives dumplings best thing here for $2.50 for 3.  Avoid the shiumai.

Avoid starting too hard at the floor and just look at the food.  

For low grade fast dumping this is one of my favorite in clement.  Until I get the visit from any critter which I will avoid after.
author: David H.

description: Probably more of a 3.5 Star but rounded up. There are better places dim sum places on Clement but there are certainly worse too. Pork buns are fine but I'd go to Wing Lee instead. Potstickers are decent but I'd go to Good Luck probably. Egg rolls are pretty decent too. Everything was average to pretty decent, nothing exceptional.  Good variety. One thing I hated was they put everything in plastic to go bags instead of a box so it got a bit too steamed and a little soggy.
author: Scott D.

description: Tasty baos! My go-to breakfast joint whenever I'm back in SF! nothing fancy but great tasting yummy food.
author: Karen X.

description: Really tasty, warm soft dim sum. They also have soup dumplings togo! Affordable and delicious and not overly greasy if it's fried. Also clean bathroom!! Can't beat that in sf
author: Andrea R.

description: It's a nice Dim sum place,love their wonton soup. Better get it home to eat. Everything is good. Service is great. Only problem is that restroom is right there when you want to sit in to eat. Hope they can relocate restroom. Otherwise it's all good.
author: Vinaisi V.

description: Just tried them for first time. Steamed pork buns are fantastic. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED. Psrking can be difficult but they're the besy on Clement Street.
author: Andie S.

description:
There'd be a queue around noon.
3pm will be a good time to go, no long queues, while most things are still available.
Things become scarce after 4pm.
We love the shrimp dumpling, crusty radish pastry.
author: majia m.

description:
This place had been recommended by friends, and I'm always up for a good xiao long bao! But I was hugely disappointed. The dumplings themselves were OK--not great but not horrible. The sesame balls were a big disappointment, though. They were practically hollow with just a small amount of bean paste inside. 

The restaurant was disgusting. It was so dirty, we didn't want to touch anything. The kicker was when not one, but two employees went into the bathroom with their gloves on and came out wearing the same gloves and went right back to work! Gross! No wonder their health card score was only a 79. We won't be back.
author: Amy B.

description: Not sure why the review for this place is less than 4 stars. They have great selection, fast service, and I personally prefer their bbq bun compared to good luck dim sum. Their steamed bbq pork bun is a smooth surface dough unlike the fluffier cracked bun at Good Luck. This makes the bun taste sweeter and smoother in my opinion, which makes me end up choosing this place more often than Good Luck Dim Sum. Great, inexpensive, dim sum.
author: Johnny B.

description: Very good neighborhood place to get good and cheap dim sum. Their steam roll is really soft and fluffy, wonton is also very good and is only $5.25! Their pumpkin cake is also my favorite.
author: Kelvin Y.

description: I love this place! Whenever I'm in the city, I always try to stop by here. It's a really small place and there are limited tables. The line is usually out the door but they're pretty quick to get you in and out the door. They do sell it out by the time it gets close to closing. So, I would definitely recommend going at least a couple hours before closing. I really like their green onion pancakes, their potstickers and of course their xiao long bao. I always leave satisfied. When you're in the city definitely stop by.
author: Misty T.

description: They got an award for best food but I'm not sure for what food. I would assume that would be for the Xia long bao, I ordered 2. That's 12 dumplings. Half of them were not sealed on the tip. There were not juicy. The texture of the meat was weird and contained cartilage. That's a Failed. For the price, it's still a good value with good confort food. But definitely not the best. Maybe that's a fake award.
author: Jean-Yves F.

description: This is a review of their xiao long bao and chive box. Both delicious and I'll be back to try other buns that they sell. The chive box tastes like how my grandma used to make it! Yes it's a bit greasy but fat is where the flavor is. The filling is chock full of chives and bits of eggs and shrimp and stuff. Xiao long bao is properly hot and juicy and fatty, seasoned well inside.
author: Mei W.

description:
Have to go here!  

Plain place? Yup.

Tiny? Yup.

Cash only? of course!

Best soup dumplings ever? Absolutely!!!!

and isn't that all that matters?

shhh ( I love their fried twisted bread thing- NOT greasy)
author: Steve B.

description:
Xiao Long Bao is a reliable good restaurant 'tho I think touts a "Grand Opening" banner that's been up on display for over a year now.

The food is made fresh, and in fact you can watch them make it from the widow facing the Clement Street sidewalk.

Their Shanghai Dumplings are good and fairly priced.

It's not necessarily of the famed "Din Tai Fung" quality but then again, it's also not overpriced either, so is fair and reasonable.

Parking is as it always is in the Richmond District of San Francisco, if you are wiling to walk, you can find un-metered free street parking too.
author: Rick S.

description:
So I was pleasantly surprised when I found this place.  I was shopping with my mom at the nearby Asian markets and came across a guy standing at the window making gigantic dumplings.  I couldn't help but to stare, drool, and make my way inside.  

I pointed to the man and asked for whatever he was making.  They didn't have any available at the time as they were in the process of cooking them.  These dumplings were huge versions of the pan fried chive and shrimp dumplings you get from dim sum spots.  Although these were mostly filled with tofu and chives, there were little pieces of shrimp in there. 

The dumpling, itself, was delish, piping hot.  I tried the egg yolk bun here but it wasn't as good as I hoped it would be.  

Service is what you'd expect...non-existent...but I would still like to come back and try other items that they carry.
author: Jen W.

description: I grew up two blocks from here. The shop at this location was my mother's favorite dim sum place in the 1970s-1990s. The management of the shop here is relatively new, but they kept up the tradition and it is now my favorite dim sum place!
author: John K.

description: This is my favorite "to go" dim sum in the Richmond. I've never tried any of their sit down meals, but all the buns, dumplings, rolls and pancakes are great! Very good price and the lines never too bad.
author: Kaitlin S.

description: Delicious and fresh dim sum!  We were searching for a quick take away place.  The food was delicious!  Make sure you know what you want to order before you get to the cashier,  their mission is to keep the line moving!  Ask for soy sauce to go.
author: Kathy T.

description:
So, I've been here 3 or 4 times, and the first few times, I'd had the green onion pancake (fabulous) and the shrimp dumplings (solid given this is fast food dim sum)--based on these dishes, I would have given 4, maybe even 5 stars (I'm chinese american, and it's not the cleanest place, but it's fast food dim sum, so I think it's in line with expectations--at least mine).  

This past weekend, we ended up ordering many more dishes--beef noodle roll, beef noodle soup,red oil wontons, shanghai dumplings.  The two beef dishes were very flavorless and bland and not very good at all.  Red oil wontons, which I've ordered in the past also tasted really bland this time.  The shanghai dumplings are ok, but even though they come in individual foil pieces, the skin was all broken and the meat tasted super fatty (maybe too much so).  Anyway, this was overall, a not very good meal.

So, I recommend with reservation.  I think the green onion pancake and shrimp dumplings are both good, but use caution for other dishes.  

And for those of you who are less conditioned to less clean establishments, brace yourselves or skip.
author: Howard T.

description:
Who needs to go to a sit down dim sum restaurant when there's takeout on every block? This is one of my fave places for a quick dim sum breakfast. Top things:

- pan-fried beef buns
- pot stickers (deceptively simple but good)
- chive... turnover? It looks like a giant dumpling
- egg yoke buns (try to get a fresh batch!)
- century egg/ pork congee with a chinese doughnut
- scallion pancakes (with or without beef)

Most times it ends up being less than $10 a person.
I come here mainly for the above items, everything else I suggest checking out good luck dim sum!
author: Tiffany H.

description: Yesterday after crossing Golden Gate Bridge we were hungry so I broke out my yelp app on cell phone and looked for a restaurant we found a dim sum house drove by the place and found parking across the street. Place reminded me of Flushing NY allot of Chinese purchased a lotto ticket said one of the few things in mandarin I know "knee how" which means hello in Chinese the guy smiled then I inquired about the restaurant found on yelp he told me there was a better dim sum house on the same side of the street next door we went to a Chinese grocer purchased a few things asked about the restaurant we were supposed to go to. She said the restaurant the other shop keeper mentioned was better decided to give it a try. The place was packed and busy with Americans as well as Chinese. They had a glass case with various dim sum behind it. Decided to take out because we were behind a parking meter. All the dumplings (dim sum) were steamed ordered shrimp and a scallion pancake and few other vegetable and shrimp concoctions  everything was on paper thin wrappers and quite delicious the best dim sum in my life. It is a little far away from me so who knows if I will be returning but if you want dim sum in San Francisco you should give this place a try,
author: Peter F.

description:
The people working here are rude. The customer in front of me were mad that this lady didn't get what they wanted. I just came here for the Shanghai dumplings. It wasn't even ok because the way she jam pack my dumplings , all the soup was on the bottom on the box. She even charge me an extra $1. I guess that's for tip which she doesn't deserve getting the fact she ruined my food. 

Not coming here again. Worst service ever. Asian ladies are tricky.
author: Miri L.

description:
More expensive,  less delicious, same rude service.  

Those are the things that differentiate this dim sum spot from the others in close proximity.
The egg rolls were over fried.
The soup dumplings lacked flavor.
The pork shu mai are pretty good.
The shrimp dumplings were alright,  again lacking flavor. 

Over all this  pplace has a lack of flavor that would normally be the whole reason you want good dim sum in the first place. I will not go back. So many options out there. It falls in to the try it once category.
author: Ben M.

description: Very cheap and authentic pastries, buns and noodles. An order of Xiao long Bao (six) only costs $4.5. Very worthy the visit if you are nearby.
author: Wanchen V.

description:
If the name of your establishment is Xiao Long Bao, you should have the best XLB's ever!!  But in this case, NO..

Driving down Clement looking for parking, we just so happened to park right in front of Xiao Long Bao.  My friend immediately jumped out of the car and proceeded to see what they had to offer, since he was hungry for an afternoon snack.  Got an order of 6 XLB's to share.

They were cupped in tin cups and were not Steaming HOT.  Which was a problem right off the bat!  XLB's need to be HOT in order for the soup and juices to flow out and burn your tongue as you say it's so good!  This was not the case.  We finished our order and immediately left..
author: Ian K.

description: Siomai at its best .. Big Serving too worth the trip ...after going to the farmers market ..
author: Donovan L.

description:
It was the end of the day on a Sunday so they were out of a lot of things including the famous Xiao long bao.

I did grab some pork su mai and sticky rice rolls. I really liked that their display shelves are labeled with the item names.

The su mai was okay, not enough fungus for my preference and it would have tasted better with chili garlic sauce or soy (I snacked on them later on the go, sauceless). 

The sticky rice rolls were better seasoned with pork filling, but at the center there was, oddly, a chunk of yam and half a Chinese sausage. I don't know if it's a Shanghai variation. And I still ate it. It wasn't horrible and I hate wasting food.

The ambiance is your typical SF dim sum place. We totally got cut in line by a Chinese grandma. Eh. But I really liked the neighborhood. A lot of variety and not as crazy or packed as Chinatown, where my Good Mong Kok is located. We did have a somewhat hard time finding parking as well but we drove a few blocks down and found something.

I would definitely come back to check out the bao and other nearby spots.
author: Sue V.

description:
Maybe I ordered all the wrong things, I don't know, but I did not enjoy anything I got.

- Pan fried pork bun: The best thing I ordered here. It's okay, but that something I would get again.
- Pan fried beef bun: The taste was weird, not as in unsanitary-gone-bad-weird, just unpleasant flavor weird, and the bun was super dry.
- Liu Sha Bao (Yolk Bun): Very grainy and dry. Not runny. Was disappointed.
- Shanghai sweet potato cakes: Very gummy/chewy glutinous rice texture cakes, but tasted just like sweet potatoes. Wasn't my thing.
- BBQ pork bun (steamed): The worst bbq pork bun I've ever had. 
- Turnip cake: Okay, but very mushy.

On the other hand, the service I got was normal. Not rude, the staff was pleasant enough.
author: H. L.

description:
The best things on the menu, in my opinion will not dissapoint:

1. Fried shrimp
2. XLB - pork regular
3. Beef Pancake
4. Wonton soup

Don't forget the sauces for XLB and buy the garlic sauce.
author: Shayenne G.

description: A hole in the wall that puts out some really good dim sum. Their beef stew and wonton noodle soup is spot on and a huge portion. XLB was freshly made and steamed. The onion pancake was only so-so, needs a little more salt and green onion. They have a shrimp and chive dumpling that is pretty tasty. Filled to the brim with chives, scrambled eggs, tofu, shrimp, and vermicelli. One order comes with 2 huge servings. Will definitely be back to try other things. Parking sucks but food makes up for it.
author: Alicia A.

description:
There's a certain irony in that a place named Xiao Long Bao has the worst Xiao Long Bao that I've ever had. It had little soup, too much ginger and just in general did not taste very good.

However, I did randomly pick up a few other items that turned out to be pretty good. The sesame paste bun was interesting and had a nice taste to it. The egg yolk bun was really good too! The pumpkin cake was bland and forgettable.

While this place was not a complete waste of time due to the interesting buns, they should definitely change its name. Go elsewhere for your XLB fix.
author: Mark O.

description:
One Star?

I want to give this place "The Finger"!

Alright.  I'm here to spend money.  Not just on a meal which I could simply get by ordering take-away, but for an entire dining experience.  I'm paying for everything from the food, to the presentation, to the ambiance, to the service, and I also expect a clean bathroom for my $100 that I'm going to spend.  Why should I spend my money with your establishment?  What incentive do you offer?  Because you're not doing me any favors by allowing me to dine at your restaurant.  I could eat at any of the thousands of places in The City.  Why your's?  

In the world of Chinese Restaurants, you expect shortcomings.  After all, you're not paying much, so you expect a lot less.  Rude staff.  Bad service.  Dirty bathrooms.  A piece of food handed to you with a piece of wax paper.  Hair in your food.  Roaches.  Fruit flies.  

I can remember Silver Restaurant in Chinatown, open 24 hours with no pest control.  Rats literally ran amok in the dining room.  But nobody cared because you were drunk from club-hopping, and you could ask for "cold tea" and have beer in your teapot.  

This is by far, the worst place I've ever been to.  

The illusion is crafted by the exhibition prep in the front window.  They want you to see that they are crafting their own food products.  The allure of handmade as opposed to reheated from frozen.  The promise of freshness.  Real food, unmolested by periodic table of elements ingredients such as MSG.  

Optical illusion.  Smoke & mirrors.  No guarantee that anything is being made right, just because you see it being made.  Doughy dumpling skins that suffer from too much starch or the wrong blend of flour, lye water, or any other mishandled ingredient changes the experience.  Seasoning could still be off.  Even dirty oil, at the wrong temperature, could make for really bad food.  And under steaming or oversteaming can happen despite the exhibition kitchen.

Walk in.  No response from the people at the counter.  They didn't even look at me.  I sit down.  They know I'm sitting there.  Nothing happens. 15 minutes elapse.  I go to the counter and ask for menus.  The clerk refused.  The clerk said that I can get in line and order at the counter.  Actually, the clerk was yelling and using profanity.  Should I also mention that I was with a disabled person, and that the verbal barrage was mainly directed at the person's disability?  How does that fall within The Americans With Disabilities Act?  It's not often that a total stranger offends to the point where I will throw punches.  In this case, I was ready to throw a spinning back kick.  They would have had to run down to the corner to get Master Tat Mau Wong to save her.

What kind of restaurant refuses to serve guest seated at a table?

The 1 Star Rating is for the restaurant.  If you're paying attention, I have yet to try the food.  At this point, the food does not matter.  They could be serving gold dipped foreskin from virgin sacrifices.  Even if I did get to try the food, and it was spectacular, I would never go back to a place which allows employees to treat customer so poorly.  

I might go back, at closing time, to give the owner an asskicking for employing such dreadful people.  I hope those b-words are not relatives.
author: Barry M.

description:
This place is a prime example of why I never trust Yelp reviews for Chinese restaurants. For starters, you can tell by the line of people waiting out the door. 

Got the Xiao Long Baos, where I thought were pretty...soupy and freshly steamed. And 6 for $4.50??? Done. I also got the regular dumplings (solid choice) and the potstickers (big, juicy, and flavorful) Perfect ratio of napa and pork. This place reminded me of the dumplings my grand mother would used to make. 

Dont trust the 3 star review.
author: Steve L.

description: I would recommend this place to anyone who wants an authentic taste of Chinese culture. I come from a Chinese family and we never skip this place when we're in San Francisco. Everything is delicious-- my favorites are the scallop pancakes, xiao long Bao, and the potstickers.
author: Ariel C.

description: Ah this place. When it first opened I was so excited. I thought it would either be excellent or very good. I was floored when the xiao long bao were doughy, thick casing and just so/so taste. I was like these suck, wtf?!   I've tried again and again coming back giving them the benefit of the doubt. No luck. I guess they are implementing a "Microsoft" strategy of providing mediocre products to the masses. I've also tried other items like their dumplings in spicy oil, the various baozi (steamed buns) and puffs. All are just so/so. By far, my favorite dish here is the wonton soup. The won tons are very good, but the broth is too salty and they waste a lot of plastic getting it too you. Love the branding out front, but time to fire the chef and get some really talent here... you'll make a LOT more money.
author: Brian J.

description:
Overall, not bad.  I've been here a few times and will likely return again as it's super convenient.

The lowdown:
- Xiao long bao: I actually don't like these.  Good texture but not enough flavor.
- Shrimp rice roll: Standard, tasty.  Soy sauce tasted a little off to me, but I think it may have just sat in the sauce for too long.
- Har Gow (shrimp dumpling): Pretty tasty.
- Siu Mai: Pretty tasty
- Potstickers: Delicious.  Super satisfying.

I still want to come back and try their wonton soup and taiwanese beef noodle soup.  Next time!
author: Melinda C.

description:
I'm writing this as I sit on a plane flying from New York to San Francisco. It's 5:19pm and I have not eaten lunch or dinner, because planes do not have food options that don't have dairy, and I can't eat dairy. 

When I am desperately hungry (actually, even when I'm just a little hungry (actually, when I'm not even hungry at all--I just always feel like eating)) my brain returns to this hole in the wall restaurant. It serves the mecca of Chinese comfort foods. All praise soup dumplings (xiao long bao). Xiao long bao are my religion, and this place gives them to you in carry out boxes with quantities as large as your little heart could desire. Even more important, they each come in their own tin, like tiny muffins. 

I know San Francisco is the land of tech, and full of innovation, but I'm convinced that this little tin that prevents you from losing your soup is the greatest invention I've ever encountered. They sell these little joy nuggets so often that they're always fresh and the soup is never all gross and evaporated, like other places that serve you your soup dumplings without the soup. Those are basically just little sad pork blobs with dough husks. Those make no one happy.

They're not the best xiao long bao I've ever had, but the price to quality ratio is on point. Dirt cheap. If that doesn't convince you, this place also has flat little turnip cakes--if you don't normally like turnips, think again, I also normally think turnips are disgusting--as well as the transparent skinned shrimp dumpling, and the delicious dessert sesame balls (filled with black sesame filling). And their soups are everything I could want in food, maybe in love, maybe even in life itself. The noodles are yellow and cooked in the biggest pot I've ever seen that always seems to be overflowing with scalding water and steam. Giant wired ladles are used to spool those bad boys out.

Shit, I'm so hungry right now. I want some xiao long bao. Please send help.
author: Nicole C.

description:
When I walked in, I was actually surprise that some of the items on their menu was so cheap. My dad, my sister, and I decided that we wanted to order wonton noodle soup and roasted duck wonton noodle soup, and an order of xiao long bao, which comes in a set of 6 and are pork dumplings that contain soup inside.

I really wanted to like this place. It's a small clean restaurant with a few tables for four. We ordered in so we waited a little while for  the food to be brought to us. The wonton noodle soup was pretty good. The wonton was filled with lots of shrimp and there were 5 of them. The noodles also come with bok choy. It is relatively cheap since it's only 4.50, but it also pretty small. Have you ever had a kimchi ramen bowl? It comes in a disposable bowl about that size. But it is a good snack. The roasted duck wonton noodles was really good too. Same size bowl. Same amount of wonton with a generous amount of roasted duck. This is pricier about 6.50? Or so? But understandable since duck isn't cheap these days.

I think the xiao long bao was the most disappointing. It came out in a plastic to go container. I love that each xiao long bao came in a small foil cup so that we don't lose our soup. But I was disappointed that it wasn't hot. The xiao long bao was the one we waited the longest for and yet, it was cold. I felt that since this store is named after these xiao long bao, shouldn't this be the best item on the menu?

They also sell their chili sauce. It's not as spicy as I'd like it, but it is good. 

Overall, this place is okay for a quick bite. Portions are definitely small, but it's affordable. I wouldn't mind coming back for their wonton noodle soup or maybe try some of their other dumplings and pancakes.
author: Andrea G.

description: This review is solely for their dim sum and wonton soup. Dim sum is delicious and nicely made. Very fresh. We come here almost once a month and we love it. The wonton soup portion is perfect for me as it's not too big or too small. The taste is great on the wonton soup. The service on the other hand is horrible and cleanliness of the kitchen, bathroom and seating area deserve one star only.
author: Melissa C.

description:
This is one of my favorite places to go in Inner Richmond for pan fried shrimp and chive crepe (honestly more like an Asian empanada) and steamed Bao (ranging from meat/veggie to taro or red bean). It's easy to fill up a clamshell box full of goodies for under 10$ :). 

While the name may lead you to order the xiao long bao here, it's honestly not the best because they often get stuck in the tin cups they are served in. 

Like many of the other dim sum stores along this stretch of clement, this store encourages to go orders. Have your order ready by the time you get to the front or grab a menu by the register. The lines move fairly quickly

Tips: cash or credit, small sit down area available for a quick eat in, paper menus are available to the left of the register

Get: pan fried shrimp and chive crepes (2 for $3) , scallion pancake, wonton noodle soup (less than 5$)
author: Julian Y.

description:
The XLB here was so-so, which was surprising given that it is this restaurant's namesake.  I also tried the potstickers which were okay.  The best was the BBQ Pork Bun - a little lean on the meat, heavy on the bun, but still tasty.

One thing that was interesting is that this restaurant charges for water.  I asked for water after sitting at a table and they said that I had to buy it.  Given that they serve salty food, this is quite the added expense for me.  I like to hydrate.
author: William P.

description: While this is not the best dim sum I've ever had, I appreciate the variety they have available and the speed/efficiency in which they deal with orders. The lady who works behind the counter is very sweet and will happily answer any questions you have about the buns and dumplings they have available. Prices are cheap, and I appreciate that they have a small dine-in area and bathroom available for customers (both of which are rare for dim sum shops in the neighborhood).
author: Michelle L.

description: Walked by XLB after having lunch at another place and had to taste one for myself given my love for Din Tai Fung. The restaurant itself is really casual and meant to be a takeout joint. While I got everything to go, I had to try one while still in the restaurant. XLBs as you can imagine, are just not a very portable food. A lot of the reviews on here claim there isn't much soup or flavor in the buns and I am surprised to say the least. The flavor is really great and there was a great amount of soup! Is the XLB better than Din Tai Fung? Definitely not. But they are definitely better than other options in the city and surprisingly better than most other dim sum restaurants.
author: Ray W.

description:
The XLBs here aren't of high quality. If you have high standards and are an XLB Nazi, don't come here. 
These XLBs are made quickly (you can watch the employees doing so at the store front), steamed, and sold. 
They're a bit doughy at the top so it gets hard, the skin is a tad thick, but they are still extremely juicy (surprisingly!) 

Had the standard XLBs, the chili pork dumplings, and an order of Taiwanese beef ramen (?). The chili pork dumplings were good. Plenty of pork with chili oil drizzled on top. Reminds me of the ones my mum makes but the beef ramen...? There was nothing Taiwanese about it. Still, everything here is cheap and gets the job done. 

Although 1 order of XLBs comes with 6, they ran out for a full order. They gave me 4 and offered a green onion pancake and another kind of pan fried dumpling in place of the missing 2. Went with it since I was able to try a variety. Liked the pancake, but they need to give you more vinegar and soy sauce.

Everything is TO GO. There is no table service. Order at the counter (paper menus) and eat at a table or be off on your way.

Bring the greens because it is CA$H ONLY but it's dirt cheap. So if you come here and leave disappointed, I told you not to have high expectations..

P.S. High MSG content. I fell hard into MSG-coma after those noodles.
author: Susy C.

description:
Okay, I'm leaving another review on this place because I over looked their cha xiao baos and green onion pancakes that are to die for. 

The 1 order (1 order always come in equivalents of 3) of baos were roughly about $2 and they're perfect. Not too much bread, it was fluffy, steamy, the pork was not overly sweet, and there weren't any cartilage. Their green onion pancakes are the best I've had & it keeps me coming back.

I still feel the same about the xiao long baos tho  :/
author: Jazzmin A.

description:
Parents, Teachers, Peers, fellow yelpers, COLLEGE students, I have a dream. What is my dream, you ask? CHEAP, GOOD, HAWWTT FOOD. Yes, that dream has been accomplished. 

I saw this on Yelp a week ago and I was excited to try because I missed Din Tai Fung  (king of all dumpings in SoCal). 

Dope Facts:
-***CASH ONLY*** dont forget your cash like I did. I was so depressed I could not buy everything I wanted to try. 
-Menus are at the counter so you dont do last minute deciding at the cashier
-they call out your receipt number at the top right when your order is ready
-it is grand opening so, yes, it is a bit unorganized. Please dont be rude to the employees. (witnessed people yelling at the cashiers for little things, SO unnecessary). 
-It's pretty small and only has about 7 tables to dine in, I'd suggest to have one person save the seat and the others can wait for the food

Xiao Long Bao (juicy pork buns): 4 stars. $3.50 for 6 pieces. Decent size of dumplings in individual foils. It came out steaming!!! Which I love. And SIX for $3.50? Is that or is that not a steal? No, its not Din Tai Fung status, but it's good enough to make me full and satisfy my cravings!
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xiao-long-bao-san-francisco?select=Gv1RDWNwn5cn_aiX93G4oA#Gv1RDWNwn5cn_aiX93G4oA

College students, yes, its time you step out of your top ramen/pasta world and enter real food world. They sell hot noodles like wonton noodles, bbq pork buns, pancakes, vermicelli noodles, etc. No, its not 5star food, but it will fill you up and its EXTREMELY CHEAP. Four stars is solely based on the XLBs and the cheap pricing. 

"Faith is taking the first step even when you can't see the whole staircase"- Martin Luther King Jr. 

Have faith in this restaurant and take the first step because even though the place looks dingy, food still tastes delicious and the pricing is even more amazing. MLK had a dream, and I have a dream to share good deals with my fellow yelpers!
author: Chena N.

description:
Stopped by for some grub here after picking up some groceries nearby. Prices are pretty on point; overall, quality is good, and I would try some other things there again. Here's a rundown of the specifics:

- Potstickers: a little greasy, but pretty good. Very pork-y, with little veg (I'm sure many will appreciate that :p).

- Chive, egg, and vermicelli pancake: loved this. It's huge, and I'm a total sucker for chives.

- Monks vegetable bao: I had high hopes, but this was a total letdown, save the nice, slightly sweet bread. The veggies tasted fine, but there wasn't very much of them, and they were an unappealing brown color? Meh.

- Shanghai burrito-looking thing: being from Beijing, I'd never seen this before. It's basically a you tiao with pork shreds encased in white, slightly sticky rice, with some seaweed and sesame seeds on the outside as garnish. Pretty delicious, and gets better with every bite. If you're really feeling the carbs, do give this a try.

Definitely want to give the dumplings and some meat bao a taste next time!
author: Shendi X.

description: Xiao long bao in aluminum tins is weird. Taste OK, but odd texture and soup. Not what I was expecting.
author: Charles C.

description: Great prices and fast service! There's limited seating so it's easiest to get everything to go. We ended up eating the xiao long bao first, while they were still hot, while waiting for the green onion pancakes to come out. The XLB were juicy, soupy, and served in tiny aluminum liners. The green onion pancakes were fresh and hot, a tad too salty, but otherwise we inhaled them because they were so so good. The prices are super affordable here. Next time I'm trying the beef noodle soup!
author: Lizzy L.

description:
The food is okay here and is really cheap. We ordered three things for less than $10. The worker constantly looked for us since we ordered something that was freshly cooked. Good to know they didn't forget about us. 

The main reason why I give it 2 stars is for actually eating there. The table we sat at was a little sticky. The sauces on the table were all really sticky and I didn't really want to touch it after awhile. 

I went to the bathroom (which was just one unisex one) and at first it seemed like the toilet wouldn't flush. After messing with after a few seconds it finally flushed. I washed my hands but noticed that there was no paper towels to dry my hands. 

Overall, the food is okay but the place isn't that clean and I won't be coming back here again. 

Pros:
-Good food and cheap 

Cons:
-Sticky table and sauce containers
author: Paul U.

description:
You know that girl from high school who got super cute, and you never realized it until you talked  with her at a party 5 years later? This is sort of like that. We must have passed this (mostly) nondescript joint a dozen times before coming in on a whim. 

Everything seems like it's made in house, even the chili sauce on the tables. Maybe a dozen dumpling options, Noodle soups and more, everything we've had has been high quality and fresh. Anything in dumpling form is good here, though oddly the Xiao Long Bao isn't the standout. 

Sitting there, watching the steady stream of Chinese families, old Russian ladies, young western couples, and you know you're in on a local favorite.
author: Patrick T.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE.  Amazing dumplings in a no frills, Hole in the wall spot in the richmond. 
Get in line, because there is always a line.  Watch people making/steaming/cooking dumplings.  Get to the front.  Point and shout what you want.  Dumplings come only in denominations of 6? Fine.  Order a bunch of food? Get rushed from the very efficient ladies at the counter who are annoyed you're speaking in english.  End up with a bag of delicious dumplings and fried things, randoms baos.  Get an enormous amount of food for 20$.  Xiao long bao are crazy good.  Eat them on the street.  Life is good.
author: CC C.

description: It's a grab and go place so don't expect ANY service. But other than that the Xiao long Baos taste pretty good. The soup inside the bun is plenty. I sucked a little before I bit into the Bao and it still have juicy soups squirting out of my mouth within the second bite. Definitely good place for a grab and go xiao long Bao.
author: Berry P.

description:
I think this is the ONLY place I know of that has xiao long bao's for takeout.

- Is it cheap? Yes!

- Are the XLBs http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xiao-long-bao-san-francisco?select=pPeMXQWWyHR3d0gXOkHhRw#QEuKoPQzx87H8v-Fsrzrww good? So-so, must be very careful when you take those little suckers out, because they break so easily. Yummm and the vinegar & soy sauce mixture was so good, good enough to drink by itself.

- Are the green onion pancakes http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xiao-long-bao-san-francisco?select=pPeMXQWWyHR3d0gXOkHhRw#pPeMXQWWyHR3d0gXOkHhRw delicious? Oh definitely yes.

- Crowded? Can be. There were a lot of people in line when I came a bit before 6PM on a Friday night.

Yes, yes, I will be back to try other items they have to offer.
author: Kylie L.

description:
The food is quite good, however the service brings down the rating. 3 stars feels too high, but the food really is delicious (and with a smile behind the counter I would take the stars up). I don't necessarily need the people to be super friendly, but courteous would be nice. I've been there twice, and the second time was worse than the first. So...come for the food, expect nothing from the woman that manages the transaction, and leave. Once home, you'll enjoy what you picked up. 

I've been a Good Luck Dim Sum customer for years and think I'll return to them for my dim sum purchases...
author: Bonnie M.

description:
Stopped by here to get some bbq pork buns and bbq pork rice noodle rolls. It was around 4:45pm and the counter lady said that they would have to prepare it and that it would take 10 minutes, which was fine. Then she said because they were closing soon, I would have to order 2 orders. What? - I said that's fine. Then she spoke with the cook and told me no BBQ pork just shrimp. I said forget it and left. 

They do have good pot stickers and BBQ steamed pork buns but I think I'll go elsewhere for my dim sum. Doesn't look like they want my money. LoL.
author: William Y.

description:
We decided to try this place for the first time instead of going to mom-in-law's usual dim sum place next block because XLB looks cleaner and not as cluttered. The  dumpling making in the window facing the street was also a good promotion for the freshness and cleanliness of their food.

Ordered pork and vege steam buns, shrimp and chive dumplings, chive boxes (yes, I love chive) and baked daikon pastry. Service was fine and price was comparable. The steam buns we had for breakfast was pretty good;  perhaps psychological we thought the flavor was good and clean. The chive dumplings were just OK, the shrimp pieces in the fillings lacked the firmness and flavor was kind of blend. Perhaps I'm just used to dim sum with more salt and msg :)  

Can't say I'm super impressed with the food we've tried so far but it's not bad either.
author: Julie W.

description: xiao long bao is on point...delicious! don't know why the 3 star rating...my first time stumbling here and it's a place I'd come back to for sure if I'm back in sf
author: Christopher K.

description:
Parking can be a problem especially on weekends.

Wondering what to eat?  They make their dumplings right in the window.  It makes you walk in to see the selection.

I love their potstickers.  6 for 4.50 the casing isn't thick and the food is very tasty.

My favorite go to item is their beef onion pan fried pancake.  Then the veg and pork bao is like a potsticker sandwich.
author: Bing D.

description:
The lure of xiao long bao proudly displayed on the banner outside brought us in, and I was happy to see that it wasn't a sit down place because I only wanted to try a few things.

The xiao long bao are ready in the large steamer and they are 6pcs to an order. The wrappers are a little thick and while there is a pocket of the juice on the inside, the meat was on the dense side. Flavor-wise it was very average.

We also got the leek turnovers which were better. The filling was tasty but the outside was too doughy and not crispy enough. It was also on the thick side.

The 'ma lai go' which is a sponge cake with a hint of sweetness was terrible. Very dense and not at all airy like it is supposed to be. Pass on that one!
author: Anita L.

description: My dad discovered this place and I finally had a chance to go with him to check it out the other week. We like to buy the XLB and other dumplings like the shrimp and chive which I like a lot, for breakfast. We just stick them in a steamer and they're almost brand new. My dad said he likes the cha siu bao's a lot and he is pretty picky when it comes to food, so that says a lot. This place is a little store with a few seats in the back just like a typical dim sum to go spot. Prices are great and food is good. We will be back to get more soon.
author: Tiff C.

description:
Yummm xiaolongbaos.  

I would agree with some of the other reviewers in that the tin thing that they put them in is a bit annoying, as the bottom is always stuck to the bottom.  But the insides were juicy, and that's really all that matters.

6 dumplings are about 4 dollars.  Everything at this place is so cheap.  It's slightly worrisome. 

They also have the usual breakfast dim sum stuff.  Chashu baos, shengjian baos, scallion pancakes, chive boxes, chicken sticky rice, etc. 

I think it's important to get whatever is fresh though.  Some of the things seemed like they had been sitting there for a bit, so don't be afraid to ask for what is coming out.

They do take credit cards also!
author: Alison L.

description: This is the kind of place that my wife and kids crave when they are anywhere near this part of town.  The BBQ pork buns are great and there is lots of variety
author: Les M.

description: Hidden gem!!! The BEST spot for delicious, reasonably priced dim sum to go! They have all the classics: har Gao, siu mai, egg yolk bun, etc. However, they're famous for their xio long bao. Lines start forming around 11:30am on the weekends, so if you come before then you'll be OK.
author: Raniel C.

description:
WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE THINKING?!? CONSPIRACY THEORIES SQUASHED!

This hole in the wall is the end all be all of dim sum on Clement st.  Don't like a hole in the wall vibe?  STFU and eat, eat you undeserving.  I discovered this place when I was whirling through a Dim Sum Tour of Clement because they proudly announce that they serve the greatest Chinese delicacy there ever was - Xiao Long Bao (Shanghai dumplings).  After I first discovered this place, I never stopped coming back.  Once a week, $5-7 gets you SO MUCH FOOD.  Actual dim sum style where you buy a ton of little things and either take it to go or pull up at one of the 6-10 small tables.  Now that I've spent some time in China and had more than my fair share of Shanghai Dumplings from all over Shanghai itself, I can put to rest the search for the perfect dim sum spot in SF because I know about this place.  

Do you feel uncomfortable because the workers here hardly speak English and almost no customers do?  Then GTFO of my way because I don't give a rat's ass.  This place is actually like a place you'd swing into when you're somewhere in China and need a quick snack.  The dodgy environment is a nice touch of POW! 

The Xiao Long Bao are a must.  The Green Onion Pancake is AMAZING.  The pot stickers are by far the best out of all options on this street.  I like the fact that this place has 3 stars because it will keep a lot of discerning foodies away, but if you look closely you will see this place for what it is - great tasting, cheap, dim sum in the neighborhood!
author: Daniel C.

description:
Why Xiao Long Bao Should Be Called Xiao Long Blah:

1)  The "spicy" chili pork dumplings were actually just bland pork stickers with chili oil dumped on top (10 tiny pot stickers for $2.99).

2)  The filling for the steamed Curry Chicken Bao tasted powdery and artificial.

3)  The filling for the steamed Sweet Egg Custard Bao was unevenly mixed with random chunks of sugar throughout.

(Go to Good Luck Dim Sum down the street instead!)

http://www.yelp.com/biz/good-luck-dim-sum-san-francisco#hrid:N0Taa0W1YFBcNWx_mnDpJQ
author: Amy C.

description: I love this place. I enjoyed their sang jeen bao, shrimp and chive pocket, and pancake. I would come back here again to get Shanghai dim sum.
author: Denise C.

description: My go to place for dim sum on clement. They are consistently good and fast. I've had soup couple of time here and it's nice for the price. I suggest trying the shrimp and chive dumplings, the beef ball buns are yummy. You can always get just a plain steam bun and see how good the base dough is. If you had twenty buck in your pocket you can eat like a king here. Your not gonna get top level service or fine dinning experience here but trust me it's the spot
author: Shek T.

description:
Came across this restaurant when my husband and I were walking on Clement Street. We had
Xiao Long Bao - 4 stars  
Flavorful filling with lots of soup in a thin wrapper. 
Pan Fried Shrimp and Chive Crepes - 5 stars 
Mostly tofu and chives with little pieces of shrimps, clear noodles and scrambled eggs. The crepe had very good texture.
Taro and Meat Dumpling - 4 stars
The last two pieces on the tray were just lukewarm. Wished they were hot. Flavorful taro and meat filling in a translucent wrapper. 
Shen Jian Bao (Pan Fried Meat Bun) - 2 stars
The dough was stodgy. The meat filling was okay.
Green Onion pancake - 2 stars
The dough was very thick and hard. We prefer a thinner green onion pancake. 

Will come back again for Pan Fried Shrimp and Chive Crepes, XLB, and Taro Meat Dumplings.
author: C C.

description:
Walked by this place....seen long line....lot's of people waiting.....everyone's talking.....I just had to wait in line to get me some!!

They just recently opened for business....and lines are out the door.

I had ordered the Xiao Long Bao and a order of Pot Stickers.

The Xiao Long Bao are a nice size and served in a foil cupcake like holder....makes ease for nice bite size Xiao Long Bao and helps contains the soup within the Bao.  Best eaten when hot.

The Pot Stickers were delicious also.  

Lines were long but fast.....there is a little wait due to your items are kept hot or cooked while you wait.

Excellent restaurant.....You can order to go or there are a few tables in the back.  

I will return for more.....got my eyes on the Won Ton to try next.

Tasty!!

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xiao-long-bao-restaurant-san-francisco?select=KOH_pdRBL0nqoGJev_3Q0g#zCBNMO7G3s97TzARThxXZQ

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xiao-long-bao-restaurant-san-francisco?select=KOH_pdRBL0nqoGJev_3Q0g#JaJ4ONyaKXapJzO7uhB37A

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xiao-long-bao-restaurant-san-francisco?select=KOH_pdRBL0nqoGJev_3Q0g#aPoSimaCge2WtiHMDWhFKg

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xiao-long-bao-restaurant-san-francisco?select=KOH_pdRBL0nqoGJev_3Q0g#QZYNB1KP85E3Qf77zVQU0Q

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xiao-long-bao-restaurant-san-francisco?select=KOH_pdRBL0nqoGJev_3Q0g#okXzoCKX_uBIcCfA7_RYSA

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xiao-long-bao-restaurant-san-francisco?select=KOH_pdRBL0nqoGJev_3Q0g#sRotDBdkM4u_6ar_aPv0Aw

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/xiao-long-bao-restaurant-san-francisco?select=KOH_pdRBL0nqoGJev_3Q0g#HrQWkAsp96NcCaC-7bzQFQ
author: Alan L.

description:
Having had xiao long bao in Asia and in other parts if the USA, I feel that this place falls short.

The dough is very thick, and chewy when it's suppose to be thin and silky.

The meat tastes fatty and has a lot of fillers.

With so many places in SF, this place falls short of it's name.
author: Jackie H.

description:
I wish it was a tad cheaper for what it is but it's decent if you just want a little snack.

Like everyone else is saying, XLB is not really their strong suit even though it's the store name. I think I've tried all the dumplings here and the pork/cabbage one is probably my fav. dumpling
The green onion pancake is extremely thick and doughy, skip that item. Kinda sucks cause i LOVE green onion pancakes!

My favorite overall thing is probably the pork/cabbage bao which is moist and tastes like a huge dumping :D

Have yet to dry the rice noodles or noodle soup but I have a feeling they won't be too bad here.
author: Emily C.

description:
With the restaurant's name of XLB... one would assume that they'd be an XLB expert!

FOOD & TASTE:
"Shanghai Soup Dumplings (6)"   Sure.. each dumpling is placed in its individual cup, but what's the point if there's barely any, if any soup at all, in it? :-/
  
"Pork & Vegetable Dumplings (10)"  Nothing fancy... just dumplings... can't go wrong. 

CONVENIENCE: *** [Located in the middle of the block, in the Richmond district, where parking can definitely be a B!  Note: Be sure to FEED your meter! ...and this shop takes CASH ONLY.]
AMBIANCE: **** [Open space, plenty of seating, CLEAN... at least for now.]
SERVICE: *** [Tried to order the Crab XLB, but they ran out?  Idk. I think they just didn't wanna buy the crab.]
PRICE:  $  [$2.99 for (10) Pork & Veggie Dumplings, $3.50 for (6) XLB.]
OVERALL: **/* [2.5 stars... too many XLB shops in SF... so based on quality & taste, I really wouldn't go out of my way to come here again.]

Cheap eat... fills the XLB craving, but not the satisfaction.
Nuff said.

[#12 of 100 YELP CHALLENGE 2013]
author: Lily Y.

description: Love this little dim sum take out spot. They also have seats for dining-in. Their shredded turnip cake （萝卜丝饼）is the best in the city. The shell is super flakey and it is packed with fresh shredded turnips.
author: Nancy Z.

description:
Finally decided to try this place out with my parents. The rating is more like a 3.5 star rating. We we ordered:

Xiao Long Bao: It was just OK. For something that is mass produced it was alright. They put them in those tin cups to keep in the juice. 

Pork and Chive Dumpling: Again it was average. They do have to boil them in water when you order them.

Pot Stickers: Decent size. Taste like a pot sticker.

BBQ Pork Wonton Noodle: My brother ordered this. I tried a wonton and a few pieces of BBQ pork. Not too bad. Decent portion of wonton and pork for the price. Also includes a few pieces of bok choy.

Braised Beef Stew Ramen: Parents shared this. Same as above comments.

Shrimp Rice Noodle Roll: Pretty good. Sometimes the shrimp in some of the dim places have weird after tastes, but this one tasted fresh.

Shrimp and Pork Sui Mai: Probably my favorite. It's a bit different from dim sum places. It's not mushroom flavor! It has more of a pork flavor. They're pretty big too compared to most dim sum places. (Still love Good Luck Dim Sum)

Turnip Cake: Dessert. I ate half of one. Nice and flaky. Not my cup of tea, but my mom said not a lot places sell it. She liked it. 

Sweet Soy: Not too sweet. They put it in a coffee cup. I enjoyed it. 

A couple of tips:
- They have a few tables inside if you want to eat inside the place. 

- It's not a table service restaurant! You order / pay first and then take your food to an available table. On a few items like the noodle soup dishes, the lady will ask if you will be eating it here.

- I'd suggest eating your food there. I was there around 12:30 p.m. on Monday and was able to get a table of four easily. Maybe other days it's more crowded? Unless you live close by, the food is meant to be eaten hot. 

I'd probably come back and try a few other things. We didn't get any bao. A cha xiao bao is a cha xiao boa. Nothing special at least for me since I'm Chinese. I want to try the chicken curry bao next time. 

Atmosphere can be kind of loud. It's not from customers, but from the cashier lady talking very loudly to the other workers.
author: Jerold C.

description:
I like that this place has a few vegetarian dim sum options. I usually go for the vegetarian rice roll, and I love how they make it on the spot. (You do have to wait about 5 minutes for them to prepare it.) The vegetarian buns were pretty good as well! My coworker tried their wonton noodle soup, and they actually give you a lot for what you paid for. 

Relatively clean place and there's never a line during lunch time when I go. A good alternative to all the other dim sum places on Clement.
author: Tina C.

description:
Stars: 3.5

Xiao Long Bao, is a quick to-go place for your dumpling cravings. The prices are cheap and the food taste good, but not great. Hopefully the food will get even better as it's their grand opening!

Food:

   * #1 Xiao Long Bao (Pork) [$3.50/6]
   * #5 Chili Pork Dumplings (Spicy) [$2.99/10]
   * #7 Shrimp, Chives, Egg Vermicelli Pancake [$1.75/2]

The Xiao Long Boa skin was a little thick on the top, the soup was good but not savory, and the meat was ok. The Chili Pork Dumplings are great bites especially with their sauce being a great blend thats not too spicy or oily. Want crispy, flavorful, fragrant pancakes? Be sure to try them here! The shrimp, chives, and egg vermicelli pancake was delicious but a little too salty!

Quick Tips:

   * The take-out menu's are near the cash register.
   * Cash Only

The Good: Quick Service | Yummy Pancakes | Great Prices

The Bad: Xiao Long Bao not as good as others
author: Matthew M.

description:
I love this place. I wish they had longer hours!

Ok, their XLB is actually not up to standards, considering they call themselves that. Expectations are that they would be experts right? No, I've had XLB at lots of other places with much better quality - the meat, the broth, the skin, everything. So don't come here thinking you'll be wow-ed by their XLB because you won't unfortunately.

What I love about this place is that it's made fresh, it's cheap, and it's serve-yourself-seating. If I'm eating solo, I don't want to go to a restaurant (wait in line, pay lotsa tips) just to satisfy my dumpling craving or beef noodle soup cravings. I can simply come here. Order, eat, leave.

I know my food will be hot and fresh because they're always cooking, always coming out with a new batch of yummy food.

Actually, a lot of other things on their menu besides XLB are quite excellent. Order any of their rice noodle rolls, or shrimp dumplings, or bao's. SURPRISINGLY DELICIOUS. You won't be disappointed.
author: Jackie C.

description:
3.5 overall

Just as I finished reading my fellow yelper's review on this place, coincidentally a friend calls for lunch plans and mentions a new dumpling place on Clement St.  Lets go there for lunch.  

Three of us went for lunch today. Queued up to order.  There's a menu posted alongside the cash register.  And a stack of takeout menus. 

Study the menu quickly cuz the pace is a little hectic for my taste.  Ever see little old ladies attempt to cut in line given the chance?  That's the kind of feeling I got.  

Yes, definitely order the xiao long bao. Very good. Very brothy.  Each one is served in a foil tin.  And we liked the chili oil dumplings too.  I also enjoyed the potstickers.  The chive ones were boring. The scallion pancake was very flavorful but somewhat doughy and salty. 

The sweet sticky rice buns were bland and too much dough.  

We ate in.  No tea or water service.  And we were each given one thin paper napkin like we were in China.  And no flatware.  Just some plastic forks and spoons.  

Contradiction - we get one paper napkin but all the items are served in plastic takeaway cartons.  There should be a more Eco friendly way.

It's a very affordable meal.  Under $6 p/p.
author: Shirley N.

description:
$4.25 for 6 dumplings? They certainly offer some of the least expensive XLB in San Francisco, at less than half of what they cost at the famed Din Tai Fung.

However, you get what you pay for, and that's not even the case here.

Here, the dumplings sit on a little tin cup. The thick wrapper sticks to it, and by the time you've tried to lift the dumpling, you've broken the wrapper, spilling the soup.

It's just not the way XLBs are supposed to be. Even though we explicitly waited for the new batch, they were cold by the time we got them: the staff forgot to call out our number.

But I'm not sure eating them straight out of the steamer would have helped much.

Besides, not a single word of Shanghainese is spoken here. They all speak Cantonese, and it is otherwise a Cantonese dim sum place.

My eternal search for the perfect XLB still continues. I can't wait to go back to Shanghai again... or Din Tai Fung.
author: Anonymous M.

description:
This New Xiao Long Bao  shop is a very nice addition on Clement Street. This  just open XLB shop has a very nice small selections of dumplings, mini pancakes, steamed bao and even noodle soup. Every item as I've seen is handmade and the prices are inexpensive! 

My order of 6 xiao long bao for $3.50 with pork was tender to the bite and had a nice sweet & salty  liquid burst when bitten into.  These little morsels are just the right size to consume in one mouthful with a vinegar dipping sauce.

 My second sampling was the handmade pot stickers also at  $3.50 for 6 pieces was  a real bargain and  fresh to boot. Absolutely a must try!!

I also got the pork and bok choy pancakes (mini pancakes) at $2.50 for 3. Actually, there more like a somewhat larger than a pot sticker with stuffed ground pork patties in a rice flour dough ( not a flat pancake like you think it is, but a stuffed rice flour dough pouch, steamed & grilled). 

I was there in the late afternoon, but was still very busy, worth the waiting time for this exciting new addition on Clement St.
author: Wolfy W.

description:
My friend wanted the XLB, so we stopped in, out of the six in a order, he ate three of them, the rest are still sitting in my ice box. 

I ordered the har gow aka shrimp dumplings, that were steamed to perfection and rather tasty, but they were smaller than other dim sum houses. 

Customer service was nice.
author: Pickle R.

description:
This was neither our first or second choice for lunch, but since we were running out of options, we pooped in here and prayed that it was gonna be A-O-K. 

To start, the place is fairly clean with tables for you to eat.  Everything is pretty much ready for to-go, so anything they serve is disposable, so don't expect real utensils or tableware! If you need more napkins, you'll have to ask for them too!  

Having said all that, now, down to the food....the xiao long bao was good, but not amazing.  The skin was a bit thick, but at least it was tasty.  We also had the pancake and that was pretty damn good.  The wonton noodle could use a little more flavor and the wontons weren't that tasty.  The potstickers were good too, but needed to be a little more crispy! The sweet custard bao was lacking in it's custard, leakiness.  It just seemed like it was steamed a bit too long and the custard just sorta got harden. 

But feeding for 2 for under $20 bucks is a steal in my eyes.  :)
author: Meshell C.

description:
My new go-to to-go dim sum spot in the Inner Richmond. I like that you can see many of the items being made right behind the counter, and it seems cleaner and fresher than many of the other DS places in the neighborhood. Quick, reliable, and always good if you know what to order.

My favorites:
- Chili pork dumplings (or bok choy pork dumplings, these are super similar). Always boiled fresh to order so they are piping hot. Good savory fresh flavor and comes with chili oil for dipping.
- Har gao. Good texture and flavor. Maybe not as good as Good Luck's, but still great.
- BBQ pork buns - small in size but great texture, actual pieces of pork not just gelatinous goo. I like the flavor and amount of sauce they use too.
- Curry chicken buns - unique item, very yummy

The pancakes are also good but not something I get everytime. Very filling and you get a lot for the $. Plenty of other good things to choose from but I seem to always go back to my favorite items. As others have noted, the soup dumplings aren't really the best thing they offer, so their name is a bit misleading.

I'd recommend taking out if you can. They have some tables but the ambiance is nothing to write home about. Food quality is great though!
author: Remi X.

description:
Came here during lunchtime and more than half the menu wasn't prepared yet.  Meaning, I had the option of xiao long bao (original), wonton soup and potstickers.  My friend and I ended up only getting the wontons and the xiao long bao.  

Xiao long baos came in an order of 6 for $3.50.  Super cheap.  Flavor was okay.  It wasn't very soupy though.  There was a lot of meat in each XLB.

The wonton soup came with an order of maybe 8?  10?  Not sure, but there was a lot.  And each one was filled with a lot of meat.  Some had shrimp in it.  Flavor was okay...nothing spectacular.  

We both left full off of less than $8 of food.  Not bad, but not very satisfied.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Its as if someone tapped into my mental wish list and granted me  a wish! I accidentally stumbled upon this place as I raced back and forth between dim sum places for  baos and dumplings. Long and behold, I find a line of people reading a menu outside and look up to see "Xiao Long Bao Restaurant" .
