AHHHHHHHHHHHH as if the heavens opened up and light shining onto a miracle! I have an undying love for dumplings and noodles so you can imagine the excitement I had when a restaurant exists that sells dumplings at a more convenient rate. 

I skimmed through the menu and it listed dumplings, baos, pancakes, pancake wraps, potstickers, won ton noodles, and even soy milk! 

I waited in line and ended up ordering the staple XLB ($3.50 for 6). I saw other people waiting too and thought I would have to endure a 10 minute wait, but luckily for me, they are larger orders and the XLBs were already steamed and ready for take out. There's also a few tables and chairs in the back but I mostly wanted to get home and indulge! 

I finally tried the dumplings and though they were less than I expected, I have high hopes for this place! The dumplings were still soupy but the skin is rather thick and dry at the top. The skin is thick enough to hold its form when you remove the wrapping. The vinegar dipping could definitely use some ginger in it also, just a suggestion!
author: Connie C.

description: Worst XLB I've ever eaten. I almost cried I was so disappointed. No soup. No flavor. After that, I had no interest in trying any of the other dim sum when there are so many excellent places on the same block! Suggest that, unless you like cold, tasteless and slightly greasy dumplings, you give this place a miss and try the Clement Street Restaurant next door. No Xiao Lung Bao, but the best pork buns and normi gai ever!
author: Joy S.

description: We came here after having ate a full meal at a dim sum restaurant.  The food here looked so good I felt like I was getting my second wind to eat another meal! They offer dim sum type foods from asian pancakes, dumplings, and an assortment of baos (both pan fried and steamed).  The prices were very reasonable and the food tasted pretty good.  The place was really busy when we came and there was a bit of a wait after we had paid, but service was friendly and fast.
author: Janet E.

description: 4 stars for the green onion pancake (with or without meat).  When made fresh, its 5 star worthy!   The shrimp dumplings were ok, and I was much less impressed with the steamed pork bun.  Small, dense, and very very fatty filling.  Like I was saying... The green onion pancake, when made fresh, is perfection!
author: Mark M.

description: Went for the name just to try their XLB and have had better on the east coast. They immediately stuck to their little pans too.
author: Andrea S.

description: Favorite place for steamed dim sum. They have lots of customers so the turn over is good and they are like a factory, churning out batches of everything throughout the day. It's my go to place. Two of us can be full and bring home leftovers for less than 20. They don't have all the variety of the sit-down places but they have good scallion pancake, shrimp hargao, steamed custard bun, bbq pork bun, xio long bao of course, and yummy homemade chili oil that is good on everything. They also have ramen bowls with dumplings that is decent. The broth isn't great but it's cheap, filling and warm. Stick with the dim sum. I love this place.
author: Douglas M.

description:
Same owners as Clement BBQ and Clement Restaurant Inc (literally 4 "stores" in a row now). I guess "Welcome to the Clement Restaurant, Inc" is in order.

I went there was high hopes that the food here will be great. After all, Clement Restaurant is my go to for take-out dim sum and Baked BBQ pork buns.

When I got there, I was surprised to see such a long line since it was already late in the afternoon. No biggie. Figured it was really good so didn't mind the wait. The line went fast and you can tell the workers are working as fast as they can to crank out all the orders.

So as I was waiting for my order, I "subtly" eye hustling the others who already received their food and was grubbing away at the tables in the back. The food looked hecka good and my mouth was watering, trying to be patient for my number to be called.

I ordered the Xiao Long Bao (how could you not order this when the place is named after this), potstickers and green onion pancakes.

I don't know why I was expecting this place to be different from their "sister" stores. But they were not. Although the food was good, it did not stand out. You might as well just get the same items from next door for cheaper. Seriously, the look and taste are EXACTLY the same as next door. 

But to be fair, it may be that I got the items that next door also sells. Maybe I should've gotten some of their other items. A lot of people seem to be getting their noodle soups. I will go back again and try their soups and update this review if it's any better.

Until then, I would recommended saving your money and just going next door.
author: Mei C.

description:
Freshly made dim sum that is stores in steam boxes! Not just sitting under heat lamps! A lot of the menu items are cooked made to order as well

Also appreciate the fact that the health score is clearly displayed near the tables. Service is fast and prices can't be beat!
author: Josh C.

description: My favorite grab-and-go dim sum place so far. Good spot in Clement Street. It has been my weekends brunch place for a couple years
author: Jiangyue Z.

description: I asked the cashier to fill up my water bottle and she very rudely said no and that I could buy a bottle of water. I know these cheap dim sum places are known for crappy customer service, but I can't get over it.  Soup dumplings were weird, not authentic everything else was ok.
author: Colin D.

description: I won't say this place is dirty but it looks dirty. The counters have a greasy sheen that turned me off. I found the dumplings just average and not hot.  Not going back
author: Lamb C.

description:
Relatively new, decent place but not amazing. One this is they have it set so it's fast but then most things are precooked and just heated up again (not via microwave) when ordered. That said, you can't really recook dumplings, as the texture changes. I think though, since we went during the lunch hour, things were still fairly fresh, so I can't really complain. I just wonder how it would have tasted if it were cooked to order instead. 
That aside, good Xiao Long Bao is supposed to have the thinnest skin possible, with a really juicy center. Here the skins are on the thicker side, and they didn't seem to have much juice (soup) on the inside. Even Foodtalk Cafe in Fremont has better Xiao Long Bao. 
We also tried their dumplings and the green onion pancakes, both of which were ok - they do give you 3 whole pieces when you order the pancakes, which would be alot for just one person.

So a good place to go if you're in a rush but want dumplings and aren't picky I guess.
author: Adrienne L.

description: Tried a few of the dim sum items here - char siu bao was tasty, less sweet and more pork flavored that most (which I enjoyed, but my friend missed the sweetness). The pork and bok choy pan fried bao were also yummy. I'd definitely come back here to try the rest of the menu.
author: Jo B.

description: I'm a real Chinese guy and this place is delicious and ridiculously cheap.  loved it!!!!!
author: Jeff C.

description:
I'm on a quest to try all the pork buns on Clement and beyond, and this was my first place to try.

I walked in, ordered a bbq pork bun for $0.75, and took it outside to eat on my walk home.

This bun was steamed, not baked, and was a completely new texture experience for me. The outside is sticky, but the inside is fluffy like a roll and filled with delicious, sweet bbq pork. The bun itself was bland in flavor, but was the perfect vehicle for all that delicious, saucy pork.

I give it 3/5 stars. On to the next one...
author: Liz G.

description: This is one of my favorite places for carry-out Chinese. Like others have said, the XLB aren't great and can be skipped. The onion pancakes are very good, the runny egg yolk steam buns are some of the best I've ever had, and the turnip/daikon dumplings with a crispy fried shell covering shredded turnip spotted with sausage- so good. Wish we lived closer or that parking was easier around here.
author: M B.

description:
My go to spot for quick and easy xiao long baos as well as spicy pork dumplings, onion pancake, other carby shanghai/chinese "dim sum".

I also buy their home made chili oil/sauce! around $4?

Prices can't be beat and the flavoring is actually pretty on point! I've had my fair share of shanghai dumplings, you guys can trust me :)

I would recommend taking your foods to go rather than eating here :P
author: Selina W.

description:
One of the best pork boa!  Purchased 5 steamed pork bao and returned the following day to buy 30!  Best eaten when fresh and steamy.  So cheap!  So soft!  So delicious!

The lady behind me in line said she traveled far from the Bay Area to come to this place.  She just moved to the country a few years ago (from China) and her friends advised her to come here because they made their baos just like they did back in China.
author: Happy A.

description: These people are unbelievable in a very bad way. Twice this has happened to me where we ordered  $40.00 worth of food and the lady only gave us TWO packets of soy sauce. I asked for more and she went OFF! How the heck are we going to split two packets of soy sauce amongst four adults, 18 har gows, 6 siu mais, and 12 xiao long baos??? You don't. It makes no sense to be so stingy on something that costs less than $0.03 a pack. I'm over this place. If you want to get treated bad and get ripped off, come here. Thought I'd run into someone different that would offer better customer service, but no, they all act the same.
author: Michelle R.

description: Haha they are called Xiao Long Bao but it's not good here. Skin is thick and just not tasty at all. However you can get this Turnip Pastry thingy that is really yummy especially when they make it fresh and not something you can easily find at dim sum joints and their shrimp and chive pancake is good too. The hot sauce is awesome. But beware of the death glare when you ask for more than 1. The yelpers weren't lying about the reluctancy to give you more sauces when you ask for it. For the most part their service is pleasant but the instant you ask for more sauce you'd think you did something wrong. It's pretty funny!
author: Wendy L.

description:
I live in DC where basically no XLB exist. So when I came to SF this past weekend, I knew I had to find some. They were okay. As other reviewers mentioned, they tend to stick to the little metal tins they are placed in, and therefore rip apart quite easily before you have a chance to eat them. Also, the meat filling was huge, leaving very little room for the broth. Overall decent, but would love to find better. 

We also tried some bbq pork and curry chicken buns, both of which were pretty good. My friend wasn't so keen on the curry chicken, but I actually enjoyed it a lot. It has a lot of strong flavors, which is necessary in such a big bun with a small amount of filling.

6 buns and 6 XLB was a total of $7, which to me is about as cheap as it gets, so 5 stars for the pricing! Also, the seat yourself seating area was clean and easy to find a table, conducive to quickly scarfing down your food.
author: Caroline K.

description: decent soup dumps .. cheap prices .. but nothing to write home about
author: Micah W.

description: This Dimsum place uses regular coy paper under all kinds of bun instead of parchment paper?!  My questions is, Is the copy paper safe to eat or no??
author: Connie L.

description:
Top notch char siu bao. $2.20 for 3. Flawless. Not too much bread, bread was perfect, meat wasn't too sweet, and pork didn't have any weird cartilage, finely minced. 

Haven't tried anything else yet, but I'm eager to.
author: First L.

description:
This is the first time I have been utterly disappointed by a place's Xiao Long Bao.

Little to no soup. Pressed so poorly that what remaining soup is in there spills out due to its thin dumpling skin. Pork is not very good, it's low quality ground pork with the occasional hard bit in it. The tin they use on these is terrible and is half the reason why the soup spills out, since the thin layer of dumpling skin just sticks on and peels right off. It was around $3.50 for six of these. I would not get these again from here. I've had both better value and much tastier ones elsewhere.

I also tried the BBQ Pork Rice Rolls and my girlfriend had the Shrimp Dumplings. Neither of them were worth it either. In her words, their Shrimp Dumplings are an insult to har gow everywhere.

It's such a shame because the company's NAME is Xiao Long Bao. You would think they would actually take pride in their main product and make it actually worth eating.
author: Richard K.

description: Still a great place for some yummy fresh dim sum. Not fancy at all, more like eating in a kitchen, but good, cheap food.
author: Matt A.

description:
quick and easy place for buns and dumplings.

love the vegetarian buns.  green buns filled with sauteed veggies, tofu, and vermicelli.
3 comes in an order.
Chives egg vermicelli pancakes/dumplings were huge. 
Pumpkin pancakes were alright..greasy and chewy. 
Xiao lung bao..$4 for 6. Not the best but filling.  Served in mini tin trays; good way for take out as the juices can pour into the tin.  Filling is a meatball size of meat wrapped with dough. Not the juiciest buns.

love this neighborhood!
author: Linda T.

description:
Saturday afternoon, long line was processed pretty quickly -- lots of Asian customers as well as a few non-Asians. Tables were all taken, but I wanted take out.

Decided to get an order of each: Monk, BBQ, and Taro buns. The woman at the register was friendly and spoke perfect English (not that this is important, but worth noting). You can't beat the price 1.75 x 3 = a meal for 2 people with a movie at home!

We found the buns to be fluffier than others in the neighborhood, a mere 20-40 seconds in the microwave brought them back to life perfectly. 

- Monk (vegetarian) contained: glass noodles, green onion, cabbage, carrot, shiitake mushroom + seasonings like star anise = warm it tastes surprisingly meat-like!

- BBQ (cha sui bao): tender and not-too-salty (unlike the usual variety).

- Taro (a type of starchy tuber): was /creamy/ and perfect sweetness.

We'll be back to try more!!
author: Ziggy J.

description: Wife and I got diarrehea afterwards so yeaaaa.....one star
author: Andrew K.

description:
To have your establishment named after this treasured dumpling, you better have mastered it!  Unfortunately Xiao Long Bao falls short of of it's namesake dumpling.  I think they may be riding off the wave of their grand opening as there was a decent line of people waiting.

All items were just "ok", nothing to write home about.  Things seem to be just on permanent steam which I think dried out a few of the items.

Perhaps good if you are in a rush, otherwise shop around for some of the other dim sum joints!
author: Christopher W.

description: This is my new dim sum spot on clement. Fresh, clean dim sum with better than average dim sum service. The one item I go down the street for is the bbq pork buns but other than that this is my goto for dim sum. For the ladies and gents, the bathroom is also much cleaner than the comp.
author: Tim O.

description:
This was my first time ever having bao (and probably only the second time getting Dim Sum, if my memory serves me correctly). We ordered pork dumplings in chili oil, monk's vegetable bao, and a small stack of green onion pancakes. For two of us, it came to a total of $9 and we couldn't eat everything we had! The prices are great, the food is awesome and I would say the green onion pancakes are to die for (best I've had).

If you're in the Inner Richmond area, stop by here for lunch! They don't have everything on the menu as they make food to fill the empty trays so it's not necessarily the best option if you have dietary restrictions, but if you don't have any or can get something that fits your requirements, you won't be disappointed!
author: Cassandra J.

description: We came here on Christmas Day and saw people making XLBs in the window counter and were intrigued. The price wasn't too expensive. We got a few XLBs which was okay, and some dim sum. We usually go to Good Luck Dim Sum around the Richmond area and we're able to mix and match the items a la carte. At XLB, you have to get each item as a set of three. Overall food satisfied our dim sum craving, but one thing was the table s were really dirty so we ended up grabbing a wet rag from a nearby table to clean the tables ourselves.
author: Ellin C.

description:
2.5 stars.
I was so excited but I really don't know what's up with the place?
I think every thing here are very weak
Weak means bland, no kick and too mild and boring.
Lacking strong features and characteristics.

I was very excited seeing the Mongolian Beef Bao and Curry Chicken Bao, 
both are Spicy, and 3 for just $1.75!
When I saw those items in the menu, I was like "YATTA!" mode.
But, It was not spicy at all. No kick!
Almost no flavor, so bland Bao.
I hate eating bland Bao.

I had the Taiwanese Style Beef Ramen, $6.25
It says Spicy but it was not.
Another no kick bland item I found in here.

I like Taiwanese food.
I like Hong Kong style food
I like Shanghai style food.
I like Mongolian beef, but is it Chinese? 

I am just got tired for Cantonese. No offense but I like other kind of Chinese latery.
But, this XLB is Meh, I'm not impressed.
Disappointed, Very disappointed.
author: Nobu K.

description:
this Xiao Long Bao is a take out eatery (this explains the line out the door). only 8ish tables available for sitdown. no service at tables. ordering at counter only.

two guys at the window supposedly make all the goods sold here. (i noticed the buns being carried in from next door).

menu: dumplings, mini pancakes, steamed bao, noodle soup (wonton, noodle, ramen), sides (you tiao, milk)

drill: order at counter, cashier et al. assembles food from food being made behind them. food given to customer. (some items may be premade or premade elsewhere).

eats: 
xiao long bao (6/3.5)
-pork filling with mystery liquid (no taste).water?
-sauce provided- a mixture of vinegar, soy sauce and msg,
not red vinger and sliced ginger
-xlb here similar to those in cantonese dim sum places.

chili pork dumplings(spicy) 10/2.99
-minature versions of dumplings at dumpling houses
-same filling + leeks as xlb
-same sauce as xlb + chili oil.

foodnotes:
-small prices = small portions
-cash only?
-xlb here is the fast food version, not the real deal. 
-too much msg in the sauce.
-line moves semifast, (as fast as the food is cooked).
author: Victor G.

description:
Four people happily stuffed to the gills for less than $25 and no waiting in line.

I would beg to differ with those who say there is no soup in their xiao long bao - even their mini pancakes were juicy and messy (if it doesn't get all over the place...).  They're not the best of the best, but they're definitely the best for the price and convenience.

The beef mini pancake (perhaps my favorite item), mongolian beef bao, and curry chicken bao were all delicious, though I wish they would be more generous with the filling in the bao.  As for dumplings, we tried the napa cabbage and pork dumplings and the chili pork dumplings - the only difference is that the latter has chili oil on it (vinegar and chili oil already come as side condiments with the regular dumplings).

Although they have several small tables inside, everything is packaged to go, so don't bother trying to save them several clam shell boxes by asking "for here."
author: Jenn C.

description:
Since XLBs have been the latest craze, one would think that a spot with the name XLB would specialize in the dumpling itself.  There's actually no difference between the ones they serve here compared to those you buy in the Asian supermarkets at the frozen section and then steaming them yourself at home.  There isn't any juice in the XLB and everything else is generally bland.  For the cost, it is also not worth it.  Ended up tossing the rest of the food since it was just not doing it for me.  

-XLB - the good thing about it would perhaps be the generous amount of filling but unfortunately the skin is too thick, there's no juice, and the flavor is lacking
-Taiwanese Spicy Beef Ramen - beef was chewy, noodles were mushy, and soup was bland
-Wonton Noodle Soup - not enough flavor
-Scallion Pancake - not crispy enough, no flavor, thick
author: Vincent K.

description:
2nd visit yielding the following:

- wor tip (potstickers): these were delicious
- green onion pancakes: average
- XLBs: I was disappointed with this batch versus a week ago. Two of the six were cold, and one of the six had no soup in it (?!?). Maybe they were short-staffed on personnel? Two different "lot numbers"? Dunno...taking one-star off.
author: Derek N.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed Xiao Long Bao's dumplings, but also have had better. 

I ordered 2 orders of XLB's 6 for $2.65? And I also ordered the shrimp, chives, and egg vermicelli pancake (2) for $2.50. 

The XLB's each had their own foil cup, which was nice so the soup didn't spill out, but kind of wasteful? 

I absolutely LOVED the pancake, and wish I had ordered more. It was HUGE and well worth my $2.50. 

All in all, I would go back but maybe try just the pancakes and get my XLB's at my usual Dumpling Kitchen, in the Sunset.
author: Alison N.

description:
I love XLB. There aren't many places that can cook it correctly. This is one of those places that does a horrible job. Dropped in here for a late lunch to try the new place out and was severely disappointed. First, there was one girl at the counter taking orders, giving people their food, and talking to multiple customers at the same time I was trying to order. It was very inefficient and frustrating.

Next, they were out of half of the menu. I tried to order six things and she said they were all out. She then pointed to a whole section of the menu that was no longer available from being out of stock. They were even out of the soy milk drink. Seriously? I then asked what they DO have. We ordered the crab xiao long bao's and we got regular ones. We asked why and she said they were out of the crab ones and just assumed we wanted regular ones. Mmmmmk.

When we finally got half of our food (XLB, pork bun, scallion cake) and sat down, almost everything was cold and tasted like they were sitting out for an hour before they served them to us. The only thing that wasn't cold were the scallion pancakes. We then got the rest of our food (Chili Pork Dumpling) that we had to wait on and was supposedly just cooked. Guess what? Cold.

Here's what we ordered:

Crab Xiao Long Bao (but received regular XLB): Cold, soggy, meh.

Pork bun: Cold, tasteless, unremarkable.

Chile Pork Dumpling (these were actually tasty): Cold, soggy dough, but tasty.

Scallion Pancake: Hot! Unremarkable compared to other places I've been.

It's possible we came in on an off day, but I highly doubt it. If you have a grand opening of your restaurant, YOU'RE NOT SUPPOSED TO RUN OUT OF FOOD. The food was below average, cold, and disappointing. The service was atrocious. I wouldn't come back here.
author: Michael S.

description:
XLB is not the kind of food you want to take out. XLB should be eaten right out of the steamer, piping hot so that one can savour the liquified broth. I found a table and I bought an order of six XLB, which are oddly in their own cupcake wrappers. I bit into one of them and I was terribly disappointed that there were no broth in the XLB, not a single drop. Flavours were lacking and the skin was not as delicate as expected.

Their buns were not any better. They were doughy and has very little filling. The sweet yolk custard bun should be oozing out when bitten but instead, the filling was notably crystallised and paste-y.

So, just because they have people making dumplings fresh at the front window, it does not mean it's any good.
author: Kwoky L.

description:
Here's some advice when you come here.

If you are coming here because you are trying out all the xiao long bao places, and want to see how this place measures up. Don't.

The xiao long bao is okay, but not great, and not consistent. Flavorful filling, and good skin, but xiao long bao isn't great if it's been sitting, which often seems to happen. So, get it if you are the forgiving type, and just feel the urge to have xiao long bao.

Otherwise get the stuff that is not so temperamental to prepare. 

Another shanghai favorite is sheng jian bao. That's listed as "pork and bok choy pancakes" oddly enough (or beef pancake too).  Onion (scallion) pancakes are delicious, and cheap. Potstickers, and dumplings. Just get them!!

Round out everything with a soup. Pick the first one you pause at.

If fact, don't go in there and stare at the menu, trying to ponder what is "best." If you don't go for what I say, just look, and buy the first things that look good. Don't over think.  If it's hot. Just get it. If you don't know what it's called, who cares. Point! "I want that!"

They will gladly serve you.

Place is cheap, so the seating is the same. It's a cheap eatery. It's frantic, and chaotic, but don't worry. You'll be fine.

It's 1.85 for shrimp hargao, Yo. And without the 1 hour wait you'd have at Hong Kong Lounge. You ain't gonna get a better deal than that.
author: Boris C.

description: Baos galore..lol..we'll a good selection...yummy goodness explains this place...their Baos are one of the best I have tried..the have the steamed baos every one so if u are a baked bun type of person, still come try it.  It may make you change you mind.  Still need to try more of the menu, but so far this place will keep me getting my bao on!
author: Mary B.

description: Legit. We were on Clement, and we spotted this new place and decided to try it on for size. We got 3 baos, which were kinda hit-or-miss. Char siu bao was great, and I don't usually like this. Pork/cabbage was good too. The curry chicken was kinda bland. Good filling:bao ratio, never dry and I had these after a week in the fridge. I kinda wanna try out the soup dumplings.
author: Vivian H.

description: Amazing soup dumplings. Truly delectable. Great pork filling. Seriously i don't know about the other food but you should come here for the soup dumplings.
author: Ben G.

description:
Not bad.  I enjoy the chive dumplings more than the XLB.  This is the go to place for XLB when you want something quick, cheap and hot.

I will come back to check out the other foods but for a quick meal on the go,   Ten dumplings for less than three bucks really hits the spot!
author: Curtis L.

description: Make sure you come during peak times to try the XLB. I think that during low volume periods they let the XLB sit on a rack for an extended period of time instead of serving them fresh. I tried to explain this to the staff but they didn't seem to care too much. The mouth feel of an old XLB is really gross and mushy.  Bleh!
author: Alice H.

description: I was super excited that there was a place specializing in xiao long bao.  I wasn't hungry, but walking by this place and not getting anything was proving difficult.  You see the ladies making all the items by hand in the window, and it looks so good.  Okay well getting a few as a snack won't hurt right?  I got one order and it was just okayyyy..... First of all they weren't even hot, they were more like room temperature.  Second, they weren't that juicy (isn't that the whole point of xiao long bao).  Major fail.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Good bread on the bao. Curry chicken was my favorite. I didn't care too much for the vegetable bao but the person I was with liked them. Next time I'll try their green onion pancakes.
author: Hanster P.

description: I got my order to-go, but they are usually very busy. The xiao long baos here are not as soupy as I like, but nonetheless tastes delicious for their price. I also found out that they own the two asian stores next to it too. Other than that, I would be back for the low prices for their fast food, but I wouldn't come here for quality xiao long baos.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Fresh, hot dim sum at 4:30 in the afternoon in a spotless storefront!  Dumplings cooked while I watched!  The counter lady explained what I was ordering to this non-Chinese, WASP American, still trying to learn but usually intimidated by the the lines, language difficulties, being disrespectful of another culture/ boorish even after all my time in SF (Hey, I'm from the Midwest.  Manners matter.), was an absolute honey.  The dry shrimp, chive, egg vermicelli pancake, oh YUM!!!  Better yet, she let me order one for $1.45 (2 for $2.25). It was fresh, crisp outside,the fillings tasty, and hot.  

The dumplings were a marvel with a tender noodle and luscious chive, bok choy, and pork stuffing.  I tasted each ingredient in a swoon of pleasure and only $2.99 for 10  soupy, happy mouthfuls!  Next time (tomorrow) I'm trying the spicy chili pork dumplings and noodle soup people around  were happily slurping.  And they have 2 types of  ramen!

The best thing is the window on Clement Street where I watched one of the cooks rolling and kneading a delicious looking golden dough, smiling all the while lost in his own world with the dough.  (It was watching him work that drew me in; I can't resist a cook's food who looks so blissful.)  I tried to talk them into selling me one of whatever he was making fresh out of the oven and was told "Tomorrow."  It was pumpkin cake.  Now you know why I'll be there tomorrow!

P'S. I read the other reviews after I wrote mine.  I give XLB props for responding to their critics.  They seem to have responded to their negative comments from what I read.  I puff up in reaction to salt and MSG (like 5 lbs in water weight in 3 hours) and 6 hours later, no puff!
author: Julia C.

description:
2.5 chinese/taiwanese fast food. 

This place emphasizes quantity over quality as most of the food tastes the same as the frozen stuff you buy at 99 ranch. They also offer buns and other appetizer like foods like onion pancakes, other dumplings and potstickers. 

Overall, if you are too lazy to steam your own frozen dumplings or buns at home then this is the place for you.
author: Robert Y.

description:
For the price, the XLB (shanghai soup dumplings) are ok. I've had far better from Dumpling Kitchen or Shanghai Dumpling King. But for the location, it's ok. The dumpling skin can be a bit chewy, not much soup in the dumpling but the filling is quite flavorful. 


Also, 4 stars for the beef noodle soup! Noodles had a good texture, broth was quite flavorful.
author: Gordon O.

description:
First of all, let me say this place is spotless, I mean there's nothing on the floor in the bathroom. Talk about a rare occurence! So kudos to you Xiao Long Bao, you've obviously grasped the concept that all the other dim sum places haven't. 

They have a much more limited menu than most take out places with dumplings, mini pancakes, steamed baos, and noodles. Since the place was named after Xiao Long Bao I thought they'd be amazing but they failed to perform any such feat in my mouth, skip 'em. Head on over to those scallion pancakes, they're doughier than I like but they nailed that green onion flavor so I was happy. The chives/bokchoy/pork dumplings were ehhh nothing spectacular but satisfied my dumpling craving. Lastly, I got the Turnip cakes which were fresh and flavorful and flaky (my god, it even has bacon in them!!). Those things were also soooo filling, my only complaint is that they were cold -they fried them when we walked in so by the time we ordered they were cold to the touch.

All in all I'd say that the food was alright, I've had better dim sum, but at $16 for three people (with leftovers) and the sparkling floor, I'm going to be back for sure.
author: Monica S.

description:
The following is a summary of my trips thus far to Xiao Long Bao.

1. Grand-opening, very excited. Not so long line, even more excited. No menu to be seen, until you reach the register. There is a rather small 8 1/2"x11" piece of paper of a menu taped to the counter. That's OK, because obviously we just want XLB! Waited 10 minutes for 2 orders. Taste was good--not very good, just good. 

2. XLB cravings kicking in every time we pass by. Not so long line, it moves quickly. Rude old man tries to cut in line--I hold my tongue, and calm myself before I shove him out the door. Lucky for him he walked away. XLB today was also good.

3. Husband picked up some more XLB today, and they tasted like pot-stickers. Today's batch has no 'juiciness'. I wonder if they mixed up the won-ton filling with the XLB filling? Either that, or they made too many the previous day, and these were re-heated. They were not appetizing. So sad!

In summary, I would re-visit Xiao Long Bao if convenient. My advice is don't get overly excited about this place. Definitely not spectacular, but A-OK. I think the XLB would be tastier if the skin was thinner, minced ginger in the sauce, and if it didn't taste like pot-stickers.
author: Lizzie L.

description: They have good prices and good food. Definitely one of the better dim sum places on Clement
author: anthony g.

description: This place is decent..My coworkers and I go to this place for lunch every time we crave Chinese food.  My usual is the beef with bitter melon listed on their lunch special menu.  Tasty and flavorful!  My coworker loves their beef and tofu with vegetables and ever since he had it here, he's been hooked! He said he can eat it everyday.  Their portion is great and very fast service.  Just be extra careful when you order, always confirm what they write down. One of my coworkers wanted his food to go and ended up getting another order of the same food to go. Lol
author: Lloyd M.

description: Review is ONLY on the XLB. I ate them at the restaurant around 4pm and they were served slightly warmer than room temperature and only noticed soup in 1 of the twelve. They are served in little tins and no liquid was in the base of the cup either. The skin of the dumpling was nice and thin which is why I'm giving 2 stars
author: PBlue ..

description:
My friends and I heard about this new xlb place and decided to give it a try for lunch. They offer dumplings, noodle soups, fried rice, pancakes, and buns, among other things. 
Lets start with the xlb. The skin was thin and the meat was moistened by the tasty broth trapped inside the dumpling. The scallion pancakes were okay but not spectacular. I did however enjoy the Taiwanese beef noodle soup. I have never been to Taiwan to have the real thing but I liked the spiced seasoning on the beef. The laifun rice noodles were made pretty well too. 
Note that the portions are smaller than normal, and prices are a bit more than I expected for this kind of food. 
The service here was weak even though I went in not expecting much. Kitchen seemed to be confused and chaotic at times and they need to invest in better plastic utensils. Food took a while to be prepared. I hope they will figure this out given time.
author: Alfred L.

description:
Pretty cheap compared to other places, but I think it could definitely be better. The Shanghai soup dumplings were okay - there wasn't much soup and the skin of the dumplings tend to stick to the tin cups... 

The mongolian beef bao was okay - kind of unique but it wasn't anything great. Tasted alright. The Curry chicken bao was also something new that I haven't tried before, but it was only mediocre. 

I ordered for take-out so I may give this place another try eating in. I'm hoping it'll be better next time.
author: Killah K.

description:
5 stars for the food, 3 stars for the service.

BEST SCALLION PANCAKE by far!!!  just the right amount of dough and fluffiness...ahhh i was in pancake heaven!  and can't beat the price....$2.95 for 3!!...we also ordered the chili pork dumplings and the regular xiao long bao which were also very yummy....but the scallion pancake were the highlight and SO RIDICULOUSLY good!!!

Only gripe is that since it was opening weekend, it was a bit chaotic.  Probably 50% of the items we tried to order from the menu, they either didn't have yet or they ran out.  and the wait was a bit long, but the taste and quality of the food made up for it!  Will definitely be back!
author: Wendy Z.

description:
This is in the neighborhood and decided to try them out - I definitely was amazed that an ordinary looking restaurant / take out spot can have exceptionally tasty food. 

I'm a huge fan of the pancakes: scallion, and the shrimp/chives/rice vermicelli are so good. Not swayed either way by their bao, I think they're too doughy but the filling is so good. I got the bhudda's delight and mongolian beef which are both excellent.

Another big plus is how clean they maintain the restaurant as most Chinese eateries in our 'hood are (very) greasy spoons (or chopsticks in this metaphor). A bit surprised that more people don't eat here, but I think that word hasn't truly spread out just yet.

Come to the Inner Richmond for tasty chinese food...
author: Dante G.

description:
I like the XLB for the price.  I come here when I have a craving for XLB and don't want to spend too much money.  

I came here with family this morning and this time I was really disappointed.  The XLB basically had no soup in it!!!!! I guess after they have been sitting in the warmer for a while the soup gets absorbed or leaks out.  We had three orders and all of the XLB were basically soupless or shall I say soulless. I suggest you ask for the XLB coming straight from the steamer! (I actually went pointed out to the staff that these XLB had no soup in them.  The woman at the counter gave me a dirty look and told me herself that after a while of keeping them warm the soup disappears!)

The rest of the food including dumplings, pancakes and rice roll with BBQ pork were pretty good.
author: Nhan N.

description:
This place is fine for what it is:  inexpensive Chinese takeout. When we went mid-afternoon they were making fresh batches. Contrary to other reviews, the xiao long bao had plenty of soup inside, tho needed the sauce for more flavor. 

The green onion pancakes were thicker than some but not too doughy when fresh (reheat in frying pan, not microwave!) and very tasty. Had 3 types of won ton mein which all had 5 good-sized wontons with pork and a whole shrimp. They separate the broth to keep fresher tasting when eaten.

Overall, a limited menu, but a tasty snack place worth the price.
author: Gale H.

description: Average dimsum place. Order at the counter and sit yourself or take it to go. Price is cheap. Like the other reviews, food here can be very bland. Lacking the punch or the yum. I have ordered the siumai, hawgaw, fluffy cake, pork bun etc. mostly the chef recommendation according to the menu. Hooray for a 94 health score!
author: J C.

description:
I should know by now not to have any expectations when eating one of my favorite things in the world - steamed bao, xiao long bao, dumplings, all things that are enveloped in a dough of goodness. 

I ordered Meat & Vegetable Bao (3), Mongolian Beef Bao (3), and 2 orders of Xiao Long Bao.  I was really hungry so I had a taste of the Meat & Vegetable Bao right away and found a huge blob of FAT the size of my little fingernail that fell out of the meatball and onto my lap - I sort of lost my appetite after that.  A bit later I tried the Mongolian Beef Bao. Meh. It would have been great if they could have put a bit more filling in. 

The Xiao Long Bao I reheated in the steamer the next day for lunch. Again, it was just a bit too dense for me. I guess I'm not a huge fan of meat that is hard like a golf ball.  Sorry. I really wanted to like this place! :(
author: Charlotte C.

description:
Disappointing XLB. They're placed into small tins, which then stick to the skin, causing it to rip open the dumpling. Yes it's cheap, but I'd rather pay a dollar more for higher quality XLB.

On the bright side, the store seems to have been recently renovated so it's actually quite clean for a Chinese dim sum joint.
author: Jenny W.

description: Worst xiao bao...mushy meat and the bottom skin sticks to the tin containers. Couldn't eat most of it..
author: Cynthia N.

description: I love this place! Freshest and tastiest dumplings for cheap. I always get the number 2. Pork and chive dumplings. Also delicious are their turnip cakes and xiao long bao. Try the yummy steamed yam cake for dessert.
author: Lucy P.

description:
I haven't written on yelp for 3+ years, but might have to start writing about my horrible experiences at places. So let's first start off by saying that today was a nice sunny day and the heat was definitely in the air. 

I decided to take a stroll out to Clement Street for some easy fix Chinese meal. I remember that district supervisor Eric mar posted a picture of some Xiao Long Baos on Clement Street awhile back and so I decided to trek over there and get some. 

So as I entered the building, there were no customers inside at about 4:45pm. Place is clean and there were about 4 workers in the front and a couple in the back kitchen. My first impression was that this joint is highly staffed and food should be great.

I decided to take a look at the menu and see what this new place has to offer. So it came down to getting the 

BBQ Pork Wonton Noodle Soup
Dry Shrimp, Chives, Egg Vermicelli Pancake
Potstickers
and of course the Xiao Long Baos since that is what the name of the restaurant is named after.

In terms of flavor, here's the breakdown: BBQ Pork Wonton Soup was okay, but not great. The soup was made to order and featured BBQ Pork, a couple of wontons, egg noodles, and bok choy. The broth that came with it was on the salty side. The bowl is the size of those make-it-yourself noodles that you make by boiling hot water and pouring it into the bowl size containers. Not much for $6.25. I'm a big eater. I would rather go down to the corner restaurant and get better quality for cheaper next time.

Next, the Dry Shrimp, Chives, Egg Vermicelli Pancakes I saw were being made, so I asked for the new batch and that I could wait since I was eating there. The other ones that were premade had been sitting out on a tray for who knows how long. Anyhow, bit into them and realized they had dry tofu inside as well. The flavors mixed well, but these too were salty.

Potstickers looked decent and they were already portioned into plastic containers ready to sell. Despite the looks as if they were sitting in the container for more than 30mins, I really wanted to try them so I did. They were stuffed with meat and veggies, cold like the SF Bay, and lacked any flavor. This is where maybe they should have added salt, but then again maybe they shouldn't because it would probably end up being too salty. 

Finally, it came down to the Xiao Long Baos, when I ordered them they were in a warmer, which I thought this can't be good. So upon no better judgment I decided to still get them because that's the name of the restaurant. Bad idea, they were not hot, but luke warm, they were dry with no soupy filling, and hard like dense small meatballs. When I asked to see if I could get a new batch the lady at the counter didn't understand me well enough so brought in what I believe could be the owner or manager of the business. The owner said that this is not a dine in restaurant, but a to-go place. The Xiao Long Baos are always bought by customers and they take it home and they come back and say they love them. The lady went on to say that she will not make me a new batch because they steam them in orders of 30. I asked why not steam them in smaller batches so that they would be hot, she said no, that they don't do that here. After going back and forth for about 6-8mins with a small crowd of employees surrounding my table like vultures they still decided to do nothing and the lady just gave me back $3.80. 

After 20mins sitting down finishing my soup, one potsticker, and one pancake. I decided to write down comments about my experience. The lady then overlooked my shoulder as to see what I was doing. I felt a little uncomfortable then because she could be doing something else, perhaps making an effort at cooking me xiao long baos. Anyhow, as I packed up my bag and the remaining food that I did have (that needed to be reheated at home), the lady decides to open her mouth and say, "If you want, I can make you a new batch, but you'll have to wait 15mins." My reply to her was, why didn't you do that for me 20mins ago when I asked you about it. Her response was that there were no customers in the shop to buy the other ones. That's when I told her to make it into smaller batches, it's not that hard to do that. 

Anyhow, long story short, THE CUSTOMER IS NOT KING!!! This business is horrible at customer service, the food is too salty, the food on the racks are cold, and basically you get what you pay for. If you want great xiao long baos there is a place called Shanghai Dumpling King on Balboa and Shanghai Dumpling Shop in Millbrae if you want pretty decent xiao long baos and trust me orders at these places if you were to take out, would not be 15mins. Maybe waiting for a table could be that long, but well worth eating there than here. I'm realizing now that this posting is a long one and the first one to be written since 2009.
author: Michael J.

description: Bring cash. This is a nice little shop for fast steamed buns, random dim sum dishes like green onion pancakes and xiao long bao (dumplings with soup), I always stop by whenever I go grocery shopping on Clement street. The buns come in an order of 3 and are reasonably priced at around $2, they also package them up nicely in boxes if you order like 2 orders (6 buns) or more. And it probably helps if you bring a native Chinese speaker, though their menu and signs are translated into English.
author: Jing L.

description: Sure I'm not the biggest XLB expert but I think this place is legit! My sister lives down the street from here and I recently discovered this little neighborhood gem. To break it down easy the staff is friendly and smiles, for $10 I can get half a dozen pork buns, veggie buns, pot stickers and onion cakes and yes I said only $10. They have a good amount of indoor seating and get your order together very very quickly. The last two times I went to visit my sister I got Xiao Long Bao for the ride home and was a happy customer.
author: Sarah R.

description: I really love this place for their chive boxes!! I think these are the best in the city. It always reminds me of my grandma's. I can't say the same for the actual xiao long bao. It's a little funny to me that this place is named xiao long bao but can't actually make really good ones. Other favorite are the beef green onion pancakes. Yes!!
author: Claire H.

description: I came in here for a quick snack of XLB. They xiao long bao was cheap for 6. However, I didn't think they were great. I felt it was kind of bland and didn't like that they came in the aluminum wrapper holders. I did enjoy the pork and cabbage dumplings. The price was good and you would get 10. I was very full from just the XLB and dumplings but decided to get the green onion pancake which was extremely big for the price. I will probably come back when I am craving a quick snack on clement.
author: Jason L.

description:
You know those hole-in-the-wall take out dim sum places?   Well this is the same thing except it's for the northern china version of dim sum.  Unique for this reason alone.

Most of these hole-in-wall places are all about providing really cheap food versus being really good.  But this place is pretty good.  I can't believe how dirt cheap everything is here. 

Unfortunately, the namesake Xiao Long Bao needs work.  It's actually got great flavor and is really soupy like it's suppose to be, but they serve each Xiao Long Bao in its own aluminum cup.  Unfortunately, the Xiao Long Bao sticks to these aluminum cups and tears when you try to eat it.  The entire time, you're fighting to keep the soupy goodness in the Bao.  It's a bummer, and they've got to work on this.  

I'd stick with the other fluffy meat baos and pan fried dumplings.  All pretty good considering the price that you pay for them.  The fluffy baos come in different flavors with different stuffing inside, but they're $1.85 for three.  Yep, you read that right. $1.85. 

I will always go back to this place whenever I'm walking by for a cheap and delicious snack.
author: Lee H.

description: Not bad, huge dumplings, etc.  Small place but tables were widely available, most people seem to come here for takeout.  But there are so much competitions in the area, and I'd rather try other places.
author: Mio F.

description: We stopped by for a quick inexpensive snack.  We ate a few different baos and we really enjoyed them.  We ate a few other items and they were delicious.   I am not an expert, but these tasted better than a lot I have eaten.  The restaurant was clean and bright which was nice to see.  We will definitely be back when we need a tasty snack.
author: Mimi W.

description: This place is yummers, I usually have the xiao long bao with red vinegar so I took the XLB home with me and added the red vinegar. TIP: it taste a lot better than the sauce they give you. I also got the taro cake roll. It was delicious. This place is affordable and delicious. I will be back here soon for more.
author: Jessica C.

description: Cheap.  Decent food.  Horrible service.  The xiao long Bao are doughy and not worth it.
author: John K.

description: Clean and quick, which is always a plus on Clement Street. The dim sum is average, but their dumplings and noodle soups are fantastic!
author: Matthew M.

description: Great pork buns and shanghai style dumplings. Slightly thick on the dough but easy to eat on the run. Great taste and meaty. Always fresh. Good value and place looks clean. Worth struggling for a parking spot on clement street.
author: Luis C.

description: Good quality dim sum at a great price. The Wonton soup comes with 10 wontons and greens.
author: Franklin L.

description: I love this place and think it has the best dim sum in SF.  Everything is hot and fresh.  Not overly friendly, but amazing dim sum!!
author: Shakira M.

description: Pot stickers and onion pancake off the chain! XLB not bad but there's a lot of better ones out there. Not your typical restaurant style spot. Recommended for quick bite and Togo. Killer prices and can't wait to get back for quick lunch.
author: Larry L.

description: I believe they are run by the same folks who run Clement Chinese BBQ which spans about the 4 adjacent stores to Xiao Long Bao.  This place is fine for a snack but it is not a culinary destination.  if you are walking in the park and make your way up to Clement St looking for XLB, it'll do.  They aren't bad, but they aren't great either.  it's a perfectly acceptable location to get a snack though.  Their scallion pancakes are fresh but rather doughy.  I would have to give this critique to their entirety of San Francisco however.  where the heck can I find a nice flakey and properly salted scallion pancake?  Is it the sourdough bacteria atmosphere?  but I digress.  oh, wait, that was the end of my review.  Actually my review probably ended after "This place is fine for a snack but it is not a culinary destination."  I was probably just ranting for the rest of this review.
author: Nat L.

description: Yeah, the prices are low but I'm also 99.99% sure it gave me food poisoning. Here's the deal. $2.99 buys you 10 dumplings. Score! Right??? Negative. The just blanch (pop into hot water) cold dumplings for about 20seconds. I'm fairly certain this is what caused my sudden diarrhea... I'm quite certain it wasn't the one bite of pumpkin mochi pie that did me in. Congrats and all to the grand opening, but try at your own risk. I would not wish upon my enemies my stomach's I'll fortune. Ok, maybe my ultimate worst enemies.
author: Teresa H.

description: The xiao long bao here is not bad and they make it fresh daily. This place is small and you order at the counter when you come in and seat yourself, so it's self service.  The beef noodle soup is ok but not too impressive.
author: Jennie W.

description: These guys are just in a different class than all the other dim sum counters on Clement.  The othes all make basically the same food - all of which seems vaguely defrosted or recycled (though still quite yummy and satisfying). The guys at Xiao Long Bao make dumpling crack.  Their dumplings are freshly made, delicious, and rather difficult to stop eating.
author: ariel b.

description: Food is ok and very cheap, great if you're really hungry and don't want to spend too much. First time I bought the sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaf, it was really good but the second time I bought it, it was dry and not fresh. And they got my order wrong. They gave me 3 orders of bao in a different meat I requested, but it's not horrible. I prefer the BBQ pork though. And they added some other order I didn't want. Not superb service but what fast food chinese restaurant  in clement does have that.
author: Joyce D.

description: I'd have to agree with everyone on this, the XLB are not extraordinary. Lots of meat but no soup! I would've just had another order of pot stickers from next door. Doused it in the provided dipping sauce so the flavor I liked was not even from the XLB. I could finish one order in a sitting and saved it for later... still didn't taste good. :(
author: Crystal M.

description: Popped in for some freshly made dumplings to go and decided to eat in instead. Ordered a Hong Kong style wonton soup and Shanghainese steamed dumplings. To my surprise the wonton soup was served in a thin disposable plastic bowl and the dumplings in a take out plastic box. Both the wontons and dumplings were obviously not freshly made or steamed that morning as the skins were dry and hardened. I suspect they were from the night before as it was only 9:30 am when I went in.  The steamers were working full blast so why these people would even try to sell stale products is beyond me. I can only surmise that they have no self respect or respect for their customers. Even if the wontons were fresh, they would have flunked miserably in comparison to other average noodle houses serving HK style wontons. The Shanghainese dumplings were terrible also. I was very upset but decided to just pay and go.  Altogether I ate 2 wontons and one Shanghainese dumpling from my order. I would have said something and asked them to replace my order with freshly made wontons and dumplings, But somehow what they did was so fundamentally wrong I just didn't want to waste any more time with them. Zero stars if I could.
author: Giovani T.

description: Just went to Shanghai Dumpling King today. Gotta say, Xiao Long Bao is a 2 star "Meh, I've experienced better." compared to SDK. Sorry to say. Maybe I will think differently once I try their other items. But you would think a store with a name of XLB should have the best XLB around. Which, hands down, SDK has got going on...
author: Vicki T.

description: okay, this place needs to get it together. I love the idea, I love the name, I love their prices, but I don't love the food. I've gone twice since opening and have been disappointed in different ways. the first time I was excited and wanted to order a little of everything. only to find out that half the menu was unavailable. okay, fine, I ordered the xlb, the chili pork dumplings and the pot stickers. xlb skin a little thick and took a lot of explaining to get them to give me more vinegar. chili dumplings were great, pot stickers were okay but you could tell all hand made by the people up front. I had an awkwardly long wait for my food but I chalked that up to new openings. the second time I went I saw they changed the menu already and took some items off. that's fine since you weren't making it to begin with. I ordered my chili dumplings and got one of each of the savory buns. to my dismay the chili dumplings were different!!! totally different sauce and all of my skin was broken. the first sauce had better flavor, this time all it was was chili oil and no spicy flavor. the buns are okay but not enough filling and a little dry. I'm holding out hope they're still working out the links and will have to revisit in a few months before I give up on them.
author: Susan Z.

description: 3+ stars! Soup dumplings were soupy enough, i enjoyed the texture of the dimpling skin too. Not the best XLBs but they hit the spot pretty well.  Pot stickers were seared to order and also quite nice. My only gripe is, they list prices by whole orders and not individual units of dumplings or snack item, where an order consists of of 3 or 6 or 10 depending on the type of item. Hopefully that system will change in time
author: Loraine T.

description: They still have a Grand Opening sign on their door even though they've been open for a while.  At first their food was very good but I think I've noticed it starting to go downhill a bit, so I've been trying other spots.  If you haven't been there it's worth a try.
author: Matt H.

description: Yea I can read but once I got inside I wanted some braised beef noodle soup (Taiwanese style?). The broth was very bland, it needed a packet a soy and a couple large spoons of chili oil just to bring it up to slurpable standards. Noodles were run of the mill..beef was tender and had good flavor. Left me with a weird taste in my mouth, and a touch of indigestion.
author: Anthony R.

description: I wanted to grab some Thai food from KOT on 5th and Clement. However, they were closed for some renovation? I walked up clement toward the KOT on 8th and Clement. Right before I got there, I stumbled on this new place! Once I walked in, it reminded me of this dumpling place in NYC. I ordered the pancake and dumplings. Fast and easy. Will definitely come back
author: Christopher L.

description: One of our usual spots and we take the kids too. We always get the beef noodle soup, dumplings, shrimp dumplings, cha-siu chung, wonton noodles are good too....the xiao long baos aren't the best so they should change their name. Everything else is pretty darn good.
author: CR L.

description: Stopped by with my dad because we noticed it was a new business while we were walking down the street. We ordered the beef dumpling, xlb, mongolian beef bun and the scallion pancake. Everything was fairly good, well priced and super fresh. . Service could be better (then again we went the second day they were open) so hopefully they've ironed that out by now. Must order first before sitting down because there isn't table service.  Wouldn't purposely come back for the food but if I was in the area and was craving some quick and cheap shanghai style food, I'd stop by.
author: Sarah L.

description:
I have recently noticed that there are a lot of shanghai and various northern chinese cuisine restaurants in san francisco and of course, i have to try them out since cantonese food was never my kinda thing.

on the second day of xiao long bao's grand opening, i went to check out the food.
I was totally disgusted with their food. This was cantonese dim sum disguised as shanghai xiao long bao. 

there should be a law against these types of fraudulent cuisine claims.
author: Gail K.

description: Love their pork buns and can't beat their prices. I always come here when in the area. Will start trying the other items on their menu! Wish they had baked pork buns but they have them next door so that helps.
author: Dawn B.

description:
We tried this place at lunch.  It was very busy.

The XLBs are terrible.  It was like eating a big, slightly sweet meatball.  Blah!
The green onion pancakes were just as bad - very thick and doughy.  

With a restaurant that calls itself Xiao Long Bao, this was truly disappointing.

If Yelp had a "zero star" rating, we would have chosen that.
Sorry, won't be going back there again.
author: M H.

description: Great place for Xiao Long Baos on the go or no frill. The XLB weren't the juicest compared to Ding Tai Fong but they are quite meaty. I would pay 6 xiao long baos for $4 any day! Great place to go! And yes, their scallion pancake is quite good.
author: Lisa M.

description: DO NOT EAT HERE! Yesterday I had their Xiao long bao and pork pancakes, both of which were completely cold, and I got horribly sick a few hours later. I only had one bite of the pork pancakes because they were completely raw in the middle!! This place definitely DOES NOT deserve their 100 health score and I wouldn't advise anyone to eat here unless they want cold food and terrible sickness.
author: Devon K.

description: Pretty good dim sum.  Everything I have tried here has been pretty yummy.  Nice and cheap, fast.  It's nice to see the guys in the window making the dumplings.
author: Pig E.

description: Since we were in the area to pick up pastries at Shubert's Bakery, we decided to stop here for brunch.  From the xiao long bao and soups that we ordered, everything was fresh and tasty.   An order of Hong Kong style wonton soup would have 10 wontons.  Other places would put in fewer wontons and charge more.  You get your money's worth here.
author: Jennie K.

description: Definitely doesn't live up to the name if the place. I would have thought that if they dare name the place XLB, it would be kick ass good. Instead, its was extremely disappointing. It wasn't very juicy at all and the skin was thicker that I would have liked. Meat tasted stale even though it was made on the spot. Saw the guy making it in the kitchen and raw meat is just sitting on the counter in room temperature. Not surprisingly we had stomach upset 4 hrs later.
author: KL H.

description: Plastic, plastic, plastic. This place needs its own landfill they are producing so much non-recycleable garbage. Although there is table service, you must eat in take-out containers, which I find repulsive. They are extremely rude and the bao are mediocre. Not as good as the place a block down the street. There is nothing vegetarian other than the onion pancakes. Cash only.
author: Amy G.

description: Mini Pancakes, Dry shrimp, Chives, Egg Vermicelli Pancake, 2 for $2.25, delicious, very fresh, good price and definitely a yes.
author: Kelly L.

description: The taste is alright. HOWEVER, it's NOT xiao long bao. Xiao long bao without soup inside is just a regular bun! I really miss real Shang hai xiao long bao. It's impossible to find one in SF
author: Bobo V.

description: well, under $2 for 6 pieces of the steamed xiao long boa, i guess it not bad.  but then since they make it in advance and may leave it there for bit, the skin hardens up quickly.  so that's not great.  it's great that they hand make things, but seems like it's not made at the property.  meaning they make a certain amount a day and if they sell out (usually before the day ends), that's it.  which makes it disappointing if you go all the way there.  service is a bit lacking most times too.  they are nice, but seems like they like the ladies like to chat with each other more than take orders so you are just leave standing there waiting.
author: Food Is L.
